head_text.subj: EXT. A GRAVE MARKER SUMMER DAY

text: It's a plywood cross leaning aslant. Written on the cross black paint which has faded: SMUCKY  HE WAS OBEDIENT. The are faded. They are also straggling and ill-formed--the w child. MAIN TITLES BEGIN.
A child's printing again, this time on a chunk of warped

head_text.subj: BIFFER BIFFER A HELLUVA SNIFFER UNTIL HE DIED HE MADE US

text: I think all these shots are LAP DISSOLVES. All is silence the crickets and the wind stirring the grass. Around the themselves, the grass has been clipped short, and by some there are flowers in cheap vases. Crisco cans, Skippy pea butter jars, etc. These two markers: IN MEMORY OF MARTA OUR PET RABIT DYED 1965 (on a wide flat board) and GEN PATTON (OUR! GOOD! DO 1958 (another board).

We can't read all of them; some are too faded (or the  "gravestones" themselves too degenerated), but we can see this woodland clearing's a rather eerie -- and well-popul animal graveyard. We can see: POLYNESIA, 1953 and HANNAH THE BEST DOG THAT LIVED. HANNAH'S tombstone is part of an old Chevrolet hoo painstakingly hammered flat. MAIN TITLES CONTINUE.

From here we can see most of the clearing, which is surro forest pines. We can see that the graves--maybe 80 in all arranged in rough concentric circles. On the far side of clearing is the end of a path which spills into this grav clearing. The end of the path is flanked by wooden poles hold up a crude arch. We can see no writing on this side words on the arch face those arriving along the path.

location: THE ARCH, FROM THE PATH SIDE, CU

text: MAIN TITLES CONCLUDE. Written on the arch in faded black the work of some long-gone child: PET SEMATARY.

DOWN to look through the arch. From this angle we are loo across to a deadfall--a tangle of weather-whitened old de branches at the back of the graveyard. It's maybe twenty- from side to side and about nine feet high. At either end thick tangles of underbrush that look impassible. AS MAIN TITLES CONCLUDE, THE CAMERA MOVES SLOWLY IN on th deadfall. And as it does, we realize that there is a horr snarling face in those branches. Is this an accident? Coi Our imagination? Perhaps the audience will wonder. THE CA HOLDS ON IT and then we
BLACK. And a white title card: MOVING DAY.

head_text.subj: EXT. A HOUSE IN THE COUNTRY EVENING

text: SOUND of crickets: ree-ree-ree-ree... To the left of this house: a big empty field. Behind it: woods. Before it: a wide two-lane road. The house is a pleasant two-story New England dwelling wi shed/garage attached. In front of it is a sign which read REALTORS 292 HAMMOND STREET, BANGOR. A big SOLD strip, li bumper sticker, has been plastered across it diagonally. GROWING SOUND: the rumble of a truck. A big, big truck. I between the CAMERA and the house -- a tanker truck with a body and the word ORINCO written on the side in blue lett short-stack is blowing quantities of dark brown smoke. Be comes a Ford wagon, which slows, signals, and turns into driveway of the house we've been looking at.
As LOUIS CREED brings it to a stop we get a good look at license plate (Illinois) and a bumper sticker (HAVE YOU H
The ENGINE SOUND stops. For a moment or two we hear only ree-ree-ree of crickets. Then: ELLIE CREED (voice)
Is this our new house, daddy? LOUIS CREED (voice)
This is it.

The two front doors and one back door open. LOUIS CREED, gets out from the driver's side. RACHEL CREED, his wife, from the passenger side. From the rear door comes ELLIE C girl of 6. They are staring, fascinated, at the house. They come together, the three of them, by the front of th still staring at the house. LOUIS is clearly nervous. LOUIS
So...what do you think? RACHEL begins to smile. She turns to LOUIS and hugs him. RACHEL
It's gorgeous! ELLIE
Am I really gonna have my own room? LOUIS
Yes. ELLIE
Yaay! She looks toward the side lawn and sees a tire on a rope down from the bough of a tree. ELLIE (to RACHEL)
Is that a swing? RACHEL
Yes, but the rope might be-- ELLIE
Yaay! She goes running toward it. RACHEL gives LOUIS a tired sm LOUIS
Let her go. It's cool. RACHEL
Louis, the house is beautiful. They kiss--gently at first, then more passionately. As he her more tightly against him, a baby--GAGE--begins to cry car. LOUIS and RACHEL break the clinch. RACHEL
The Master of Disaster awakes. This SOUND is joined by the unhappy yowling of a pent-up LOUIS
And Buckaroo Banzai. RACHEL
Come on--let's parole 'em. They walk to the car, RACHEL going to one of the back sea LOUIS to the rear of the wagon.

location: THE FRONT SEAT, WITH RAHEL AND GAGE

text: GAGE is sitting in his car seat, not exactly crying but c yelling to be let out. The seat, dash, and floorboards ar littered with roadmaps, soda cans, Big Mac boxes, and sim crud. These folks have driven all the way from Chicago to this station wagon, and the wagon looks it. RACHEL
Decided to wake up and see what home looks like, huh? She begins to unbuckle the straps and harnesses. GAGE is wearing a t-shirt and a diaper. He's fifteen months old.

location: THE REAR OF THE WAGON, WITH LOUIS

text: He opens the doorgate and lifts out a cat carrier. We see tomcat inside--mostly what we're aware of are shining gre ELLIE (voice)
Daddy! Mommy! I see a path! LOUIS, cat carrier still in hand, turns toward:
She's got it penduluming back and forth in long wide arcs
We see the field, and a clearly marked and mown path lead its flank and into the dark woods. THE CAMERA DIPS AND PENDULUMS as ELLIE swings.

location: RACHEL AND GAGE, (FRONT OF THE CAR)

text: RACHEL (irritated)
Not so high, Ellie! You don't know how strong that rope is. She puts GAGE down. He totters a bit on his little legs a stands there, looking at his sister.

location: THE ROPE AND THE BRANCH, CU

text: The bark has rubbed off the branch--it looks like a bone through decayed flesh. The rope is old, discolored. And i fraying away as we look at it. Soon ELLIE, like Humpty Du going to have a great fall.
He's set the cat-carrier down and is straightening up. ELLIE (raptuous voice)
Wheee! LOUIS
Ellie, you heard your m--- His eyes widen.
ELLIE

Wh-- SOUND: A heavy twang! as the rope breaks. The tire swing- ELLIE still inside it--goes crashing to the grass. ELLIE and begins to cry--a little hurt and a lot surprised. LOUIS and RACHEL run to her.
Ellie! Are you all right?        Honey? Are you okay?
ELLIE'S parents reach the tangle of tire, rope, and six-y girl. ELLIE
Hurrts! It hurrrrts! LOUIS
Anyone who can scream that loud isn't ready for intensive care just yet-- looks like she just skinned her knee. Nevertheless, he begins to rapidly disentangle his daught the tire. RACHEL helps.

He's standing in the driveway by the front of the car, ut forgotten in the heat of the moment. His diaper is saggin bit; the boy needs a change. He stares toward the scene of the accident for a bit, the interest. CAMERA FOLLOWS as he walks down the side of the wagon, little bare feet slapping on the asphalt. He stops moment at the back, looking at the cat-carrier, which LOU got around to opening. CHURCH is staring hopefully out th mesh. GAGE
Hi-Durch! CHURCH

Waow! GAGE bends down and tries to open the cat-carrier's door. Either he can't solve the latch or his fingers don't have strength. Anyway, he stops trying after a moment. SOUND: Growing thunder of an approaching truck - a big on
A big tanker truck--silver body, ORINCO written on the si blue letters--blasts by.
The windlash if the passing truck blows GAGE'S hair back forehead. We should be scared here--not by the truck, but GAGE'S lack of fear. He's smiling, happy. GAGE
Druck! He starts down the driveway toward the road.

ELLIE has been disentangled from the swing. She's sitting wreckage at the end of the driveway, weeping hysterically from tiredness as from pain, I think) as LOUIS and RACHEL her scraped knee. The wound doesn't look too serious. LOUIS (to RACHEL)
Would you get the first aid kit? ELLIE (screaming)
Not the stingy stuff! I don't want the stingy stuff, daddy! RACHEL suddenly looks around toward:

location: THE FRONT OF THE WAGON, (RACHEL'S POV)

text: No one there.

location: RACHEL, ELLIE, LOUIS, BY THE SWING

text: RACHEL
Gage's gone! LOUIS
Jesus, the road! They get up together.

location: GAGE, AT THE EDGE OF THE ROAD

text: A truck is coming. A great big one.
The grille looks like a tombstone that's learned how to s

He takes a step into the road...and then big, gnarled han him. GAGE looks rather surprised at this, but not worried--thi used to being picked up and treated humanely. To GAGE str are as interesting as...well, as interesting as Orinco tr

The fellow who has picked GAGE up is a man of about eight blue jeans, a faded Bruce Springsteen t-shirt. Over this a faded khaki vest with bright silver buttons. His face i wrinkled and kindly. JUD CRANDALL (to GAGE)
No you don't, my friend--not in that road. But he softens this with a grin. GAGE grins back at him. GAGE
Drucks! JUD (low)
No shit, Sherlock. JUD carries him up the driveway to the station wagon. Her joined by LOUIS and RACHEL, out of breath and really scar brings up the rear. She's still sniffling. RACHEL
Gage! JUD (hands him to her)
He was headed for the road, looked like. I corralled him for you, missus. RACHEL
Thank you. Thank you so much. LOUIS
Yes--thanks. I'm Louis Creed. He sticks out his hand and JUD shakes it. LOUIS takes it crushing JayCees grip, or anything like that--the old guy if he might have arthritis. JUD
Jud Crandall. I live just across the road. RACHEL
I'm Rachel. Thanks again for saving the wandering minstrel boy, here. JUD
No harm, no foul. But you want to watch out for that road. Those damn trucks go back and forth all day and most of the night. He leans over toward ELLIE. JUD
Who might you be, little Miss? ELLIE
I'm Ellen Creed and I live at 642 Alden Lane, Dearborn, Michigan. (Pause) At least, I used to. JUD
And now you live on Route 9 in Ludlow, and your dad's gonna be the new doctor up to the college, I hear, and I think you're going to be just as happy as a clam here, Ellen Creed. ELLIE (to LOUIS)
Are clams really happy? They all laugh--even GAGE. RACHEL
Excuse me, Mr. Crandall--I've got to change this kid. It's nice to meet you. JUD
Same here. Come over and visit when you get the chance. As RACHEL, carrying GAGE, moves away: ELLIE (worries)
Daddy, do I really have to have the stingy stuff? LOUIS
No-I guess not. ELLIE
Yayyy! She goes belting off. JUD (amused)
I guess your daughter there ain't going to die after all. LOUIS (also amused)
I guess not. JUD
House has stood empty for too long. It's damn good to see people in it again. SOUND: A truck engine, gearing down.
It blinks and comes lumbering into the Creed's driveway.
LOUIS
Hey--they actually found the place! JUD
Movin' in's mighty thirsty work. I usually sit out on my porch of an evening and pour a couple of beers over m'dinner. Come on over and join me, if you want. LOUIS
Well, maybe I---- RACHEL (voice)
Louis, what's this?

GAGE has been changed, and RACHEL is following him as he the nearest edges of the new homestead. They are fairly c the wreckage of the tire swing, and here is the head of t ELLIE has already glimpsed.
They cross to the van. The FIRST and SECOND MOVERS are ju climbing out of the van. FIRST MOVER
You Mr. Creed? LOUIS
Yes. Just a second.

location: RACHEL AND GAGE, AT THE HEAD OF THE PATH

text: She's holding GAGE on her hip now, and both of them are l that strange (and oddly enticing) path which disappears i deepening twilight. LOUIS and JUD join them. LOUIS
The movers-- RACHEL
Yes--I know. This path, Louis? Where does it go? LOUIS
I don't have the slightest idea. When I saw the house, this field was under four feet of snow. RACHEL (smiling)
I bet Mr. Crandall knows! JUD nods. He smiles, too, but underneath the smile we sen he is serious. JUD

Oh, ayuh! I know. It's a good story, and a good walk, too. I'll take you up there sometime, and tell you the story, too-- after you get settled in. He smiles at them and they smile back--it is a look of  understanding and real liking, in spite of the age differ between the CREEDS and JUD.

SOUND: Crickets. Ree--ree--ree-ree...  There's one light upstairs, one downstairs. Perhaps we se path, glimmering away into the field? Either by virtue of mown, or by virtue of some gentle optical trick? Maybe.

There's a light on in the kitchen, but it just casts a di here. The room has a fireplace and a lovely wooden floor. going to be nice, but now it's just a big bare box with m cartons stacked all over the place. LOUIS is drinking a can of Pepsi, and he looks pretty dam tired--anyone who's ever moved house and can remember the night in the new place will understand. He finishes the last of the Pepsi and surveys the living sits on one of the bigger boxes, takes cigarettes from hi and lights one. He drops the spent match in the empty can taps into the can during the scene. SOUND: Feet coming down the stairs. The door on the far s the room opens and RACHEL comes in, wearing a nightgown. RACHEL (crossing to LOUIS)
Kids are asleep, doc. LOUIS
Great. He hugs her. She hugs him back warmly--for a moment they two good people in all the big darkness of their new hous RACHEL
You're not really going over to have a beer with that old guy, are you? LOUIS
Well, I've got a million questions about the area, and--- RACHEL
---and you'll end up doing a free consultation on his arthritis or urinary problems and--- LOUIS
Did you see his shirt? RACHEL (giggles)
Sure. Bruce Springsteen. LOUIS

I really do have a million questions about the area...but the thing I'm really curious about is how come this octogenarian Yankee is decorating the slumped remains of his pecs with the Boss. She laughs.

head_text.subj: EXT. THE PATH OF THE CRANDALL HOUSE NIGHT

text: Pervasive SOUND of the crickets as LOUIS comes rather hes up the crazy-paved path from the road's edge. JUD (voice)
That you, doc?

location: THE SCREENED-IN PORCH OF THE CRANDALL HOUSE

text: We hear the SQUEAK of a rocker; we see the dim red fitful JUD'S Pall Mall. We see by its glow that he is wearing Wa earphones.
LOUIS
It's me.
The Walkman is in his lap. He switches it off and puts th headphones casually around his neck, like a kid. JUD
Well, come on up and have a beer.
LOUIS comes on up. JUD has got a pail of ice beside his c some cans of beer in it. He opens one and hands it to LOU JUD
You need a glass? LOUIS
Not at all. JUD
Good for you. LOUIS drinks half the can at a draught. LOUIS
God, that's fine. JUD
Ain't it just? The man who invented beer, Louis, that man was having a prime day for himself. LOUIS
What were you listening to? JUD
Allman Brothers. LOUIS
What? JUD

The Eat A Peach album. God, they were good before drugs and bad luck caught up with them. Listen to this, Louis. He passes the headphones over. LOUIS puts them on. JUD pr Walkman's PLAY button. SOUND: Ramblin' Man blasts us out of our seats. LOUIS winces and rakes the spidery earphones off his head JUD
I'm sorry. Wait. He turns it down. JUD
Try that. LOUIS puts the earphones back on and listens for a few mo It's the instrumental break. Gregg and Duane Allman dueli Fenders. LOUIS takes the earphones off. LOUIS
Nice. JUD

I like rock and roll. No...I guess that's too mild. I love it. Since my ears started to die out on me, it's the only music I can really hear. And since my wife died...I dunno, some- times a little rock and roll fills up night. Not always, but sometimes. (Pause) One more time--welcome to Ludlow. Hope your time here will be a happy one. LOUIS (great sincerity)
Thank you, Mr. Crandall. He drinks again--they both do. There's a moment of compan silence here, broken by the SOUND of a big truck. They lo toward:

head_text.subj: EXT/INT. THE ROAD, (THROUGH THE PORCH SCREEN)

text: One of those big tanker trucks goes rumbling by--now ther little amber running lights on top of it. It's going fast sweeps by in a blast of air.

location: THE PORCH, WITH LOUIS AND JUD

text: LOUIS (wincing)
Jesus! JUD (lights a cigarette)
That's one mean road, all right--you remember that path your wife commented on? LOUIS
The one that goes into the woods--sure. JUD
That road--and those Orinco trucks-- are the two main reasons it's there. LOUIS
What's at the end of it? JUD (smiles)
Another day--after you get settled in a bit. Meantime, doc--- Here JUD raises his glass in a toast. JUD (continues)
Here's to your bones. LOUIS clinks his glass against JUD'S. LOUIS
And yours. They drink.

LOUIS crosses from the CRANDALL side to his own, and the FOLLOWS as he walks slowly up the driveway and past the w pauses for a moment, looking thoughtfully--hopefully--at house. Then something--the CRY of an OWL, perhaps--draws attention the other way...toward the path. He walks to its head and stands looking out at it--it gli a wide cut swath that's a bit ghostly in the dark. A SHAPE suddenly lurches out of the high grass at him, an recoils with a startled, muffled cry.
The cat, sure; who--or what--else? We see his big green e the dark as he cries his strange feline hello: Waow!

location: LOUIS AND CHURCH, AT THE HEAD OF THE PATH

text: LOUIS
Church! God, you scared the life out of me! CHURCH
Waow! LOUIS bends and picks up the cat. As he does, that truck comes again and he looks toward:
Another Orinco tanker drones by, fast.
LOUIS (to the cat)
I know one thing that will keep you home, good buddy. He starts toward the house. BLACK. And in that blackness, we see a second title card: SPEAK.

head_text.subj: INT. A KITCHEN BLACKBOARD, CU DAY

text: Written on it is: MONDAY 1.) CHURCH SPAYED 10 A.M. QUENTI JOLANDER, D.V.M. And below, in even bigger letters: 2.) E

THE CAMERA PANS LEFT, showing us the kitchen. There are s few cardboard cartons around, but the place is getting in We look out the window and see the CREEDS, led by JUD CRA climbing the path toward the woods. LOUIS has got GAGE in Gerrypak.

location: AT THE TOP OF THE HILL, WITH CREEDS AND JUD

text: They are also at the edge of the woods. JUD stops and let catch up. JUD
Take a look behind you. They turn around, and their faces express their wonder. LOUIS
My God! RACHEL
It's beautiful!

It is indeed beautiful. The CREED house is in the f.g., R just behind it (with one of the ever-present Orinco truck along), but behind that is the great sweep of the Penobsc valley, dozing under a fall sky of clear blue.

location: AT THE TOP OF THE HILL, WITH JUD AND THE CREEDS

text: JUD
You folks ready to go on? LOUIS
Sure. ELLIE
But where are we going, Mr. Crandall? JUD
You'll see soon enough, hon. They go into the woods, still following the path.

These are old woods indeed--huge trunks with dusty sunlig shafting through them. It looks as though man has never m mark here. THE CAMERA PANS SLOWLY DOWN to them, on the path. Here it carpeted with pine needles, but it is just as clearly mar JUD stops. LOUIS looks glad of the rest; he's sweating an are wide dark patches under his arms where the Gerrypak's are. LOUIS
Who owns the woods up ahead? Paper companies? JUD
Nope. The Micmac Indians. What's up ahead is all that's left of their tribal lands. ELLIE (giggling)
Micmac, Ricmac, Kickmac, Sickmac. JUD (smiles)
Ayuh, it's a funny word, ain't it? You tired of totin' that yowwen yet, doc? LOUIS
Not yet...how much further is it? JUD
Aw, you'll be okay. Less than a mile. He starts off again, fresh as a daisy. ELLIE scampers aft LOUIS rolls his eyes at his wife and RACHEL rolls hers ba they press on.

location: JUD AND THE CREEDS, ON THE PATH

text: JUD (stopping)
This is the place, honey. ELLIE is of course second. Se tries to read the words on but can't. She whips around to look at her mother. ELLIE
What's it say, mommy? A strange expression has come over RACHEL'S face--she doe this. Not a bit. RACHEL
It says Pet Cemetery, hon. It's misspelled, but...that's what it says. She runs for the arch. RACHEL starts; looks more uneasy t RACHEL
Ellen--!
She's almost under the arch. She looks back, questioning.
RACHEL (a bit lame)
Be careful.
She goes racing into the Pet Sematary.
JUD lights a cigarette with a wooden match, using his thu JUD
I told you it was a bad road, Louis--it's killed a lot of pets and made a lot of kids unhappy. But at least something good come of it. This place. ELLIE (excited voice)
Mom! Dad! Y'oughtta see it!

location: ELLIE, AT THE EDGE OF THE SEMATARY

text: She surveys the rude markers with puzzled delight, then r toward the center, pausing to investigate some of the mar she goes. We clearly see the symmetrical pattern of rings
They are walking slowly toward that rude archway. LOUIS i extremely interested in all this, but it's becoming clear clearer that RACHEL is troubled. They stop and look in. RACHEL
How can you call it a good thing? A graveyard for pets killed in the road! Built and maintained by broken- hearted children! JUD
Well, but Missus Creed! It ain't quite that way, deah! LOUIS
I think it's rather extraordinary. RACHEL
Extraordinarily morbid, maybe. She's growing more and more upset. JUD looks at her curio JUD
Well...they have to learn about death somehow, now don't they, Missus Creed? The little ones? RACHEL (coldly)
Why? JUD
Well...well, because-- ELLIE (voice)
Mommy! Daddy! Look at me!

She has begun to climb it, and this looks like an extreme dangerous proposition. ELLIE, however, is having the time life. A branch breaks under one of her feet and she switc nimbly to the next one up.
JUD (alarmed)
No, honey! You don't want to go climbing on that! Come on down! He hurries in.
She looks back at JUD. ELLIE
It's okay, Mr. Crandall--
The branch she's on breaks with a dry CRRRACK. Her foot d suddenly.
She totters backward, pinwheeling her arms, and JUD catch she falls. Not much of a catch because she wasn't too far LOUIS joins JUD and ELLIE. GAGE jounces along on his back LOUIS
Have you got a death-wish, Ellen? ELLIE
Well, I thought it was safe-- JUD
Best never to go climbing on old blowdowns like this, Ellie--sometimes they bite. ELLIE
Bite? JUD
Ayuh.
Her discomfort makes one thing very clear--she doesn't wa come in. RACHEL (calls)
Is she all right, Louis?
LOUIS (calls back)
Fine! Come and see!
RACHEL (calling)
I think I'll sit this one out, doc.
ELLIE
I want to look around, daddy-- may I? LOUIS
For a little while. JUD looks toward:

location: RACHEL AT THE ARCH, (ELLEN IN F.G.)

text: RACHEL has retreated a bit. She sits on the pine needle c the path, opens her purse, and draws out cigarettes.
JUD looks at LOUIS as if to say "What's all this about?" looks away. ELLIE (voice)
Dad! Daddy! Look! A goldfishie!
She runs from one tombstone to the next, cheerful as mayb kid could be in such a place. She looks at BIFFER'S tombs SMUCKY'S.
They are walking slowly toward her. LOUIS is looking at t tombstones. LOUIS
I can hardly read these. JUD

Ayuh--they get older as you go toward the middle. (Points) Pete LaVasseur's dog is buried there... (points) the Stoppard boys' racing pigeon that Missus Cowley's cat  got...and I think that's the cat  himself right there, although it's been so many years I can't tell for sure. (calling)
Missy Ellen! Come over here just a  minute!
She runs amid the tombstones--they have worked their way the center and there are quite a few of them--and joins t adults. JUD
I see you're quite a reader for such a little girl. Can you read that? He points again, and Ellen goes over for a look-see.
It is a small slate marker slanted to one side. ELLEN rea words laboriously, tracing them with her finger. ELLEN
"Spot a good fellow we love you boy." (Pause) "Owned by Judson...Judson..." Gee, I can't read the rest.
JUD
Last name's Crandall, little missy. LOUIS looks at him sharply as ELLIE rejoins them. JUD

That's where I buried my dog Spot when he died of old age in 19 and 14. Dug it good and deep. By the time I finished, I had blisters all over my hands and a hell of a crick in my back. Soil's stony up here. ELLIE looks awed. LOUIS looks a little awed, too. JUD sweeps a hand around, indicating the whole sematary, still looking at ELLEN. JUD
Do you know what this place is, Ellie? Oh, I know you know it's a boneyard, but a bone ain't nothing and even a whole pile of 'em don't amount to much. Do you know what a graveyard really is? ELLIE
Well...I guess not. JUD
It's a place where the dead speak, Missy. He sees her startled, uneasy expression and laughs. He ru hair reassuringly. JUD
No--not right out loud. Their stones speak...or their markers. Even if the  marker ain't nothing but a tin can someone wrote on with a Magic Marker, it speaks. Ain't that so, Louis? LOUIS
I think it is so, Ellie. ELLIE
What if you can't read what's written on there anymore? JUD
Well, it still says some animal got laid down here after, don't it? ELLIE
Yes-- LOUIS
And that someone cared enough about that animal to mark the spot. ELLIE
To remember. JUD (smiles)
Yes. To remember. This ain't a scary place, Ellie. It's a place of rest and speaking. Can you remember that? ELLIE (a little awed)
Yes, sir. They start to walk slowly back toward the arch.
It's clear she's impatient and out-of-sorts with the whol RACHEL (calls)
Louis, can we go? I'm tired!
ELLIE
Mommy! This is a place where dead animals talk! Mr. Crandall said so!
But RACHEL is not amused. She doesn't like any of this. RACHEL (soft)
Did he.
LOUIS
My wife is not crazy about cemeteries of any kind. As you may have noticed. JUD
Me neither. But I believe in knowing your enemy. LOUIS looks at him, startled, then decides this is a joke laughs. JUD smiles, a trifle thinly.
The men rejoin RACHEL and ELLIE. LOUIS (voice)
Did we take too long? RACHEL (curt)
Well, if supper's burned, I'm not the one going out for pizza. They move away.
The face we saw at the beginning of the movie wasn't ther the visitors were there...but it's sure there now, leerin

head_text.subj: INT. THE KITCHEN TRASH CAN NIGHT

text: There are two greasy boxes poking out with NAPOLI PIZZA s them. Guess dinner was burned. THE CAMERA PULLS BACK and we se LOUIS sitting at the kitc table. The table is covered with newspapers. On it, LOUIS putting together a complicated model boat, using glue and tweezers. He's wearing glasses. ELLIE comes in, wearing a nightgown. She watches him for LOUIS (not looking around)
Hi, babe. ELLIE
Daddy, that Pet Sematary is there because of the road, isn't it? LOUIS looks around at her, surprised. ELLIE
That's what I think. I heard Missy Dandridge tell Mom when Church was fixed he wouldn't cross the road so much. LOUIS
Well, it's always better to take precautions--but I'm sure Church will be all right, honey...
RACHEL is coming along with some dirty dishes. She hears and stops, listening, her face troubled and afraid. ELLIE (voice)
No he won't! Not in the end! He won't be all right in the end no matter how you fix 'im!
Ellis has started to cry. ELLIE
In the end he's gonna croak, isn't he? LOUIS
Lovey...Church might be still alive when you're in a high school...and that's a very long time. ELLIE

It doesn't seem long to me. It seems short. I think the whole thing about pets dying s-s-sucks! Poor kid's bawling her eyes out now. LOUIS folds her into and she hugs him tightly, wanting his comfort. LOUIS
If it was up to me I'd let Church live to be a hundred...but I don't make up the rules. ELLIE (muffled)
Well who does? God, I suppose. But he's not God's cat! He's my cat! Let God get His own, if He wants one! Not mine! Not mine! Not-- She breaks down completely, sobbing, and LOUIS rocks her forth.

location: THE HALLWAY OUTSIDE THE KITCHEN, WITH RACHEL

text: She is crying silently.
She is a dimly perceived hump in the darkness. An oblong light falls on her, illuminating her more clearly. She's with her teddy encircled by one arm and her thumb corked mouth.
RACHEL looks at her daughter with infinite love and then closes the door.

head_text.subj: INT. LOUIS'S AND RACHEL'S BEDROOM NIGHT

text: LOUIS is in his pajamas, propped up on pillows on his sid bed. There a number of medical books scattered around him making notes from one as RACHEL comes in. RACHEL
She's finally asleep. LOUIS
She was a little over-excited, that's all. Poor kid. RACHEL
It was that place. That creepy cemetery up in the woods. Whatever disease the kids in this town have got, I don't want Ellie to catch it. LOUIS
Jesus, Rachel, what's got into you? RACHEL

Do you think I didn't hear her tonight, crying as if her heart would break? Here she is thinking Church is going to die. It should be clear to us by now that, despite her words, much more upset than ELLIE was. LOUIS slowly puts his not aside and caps his pen. LOUIS
Rachel...someday Church is going to  die. RACHEL (whirls on him)

That is hardly the point! Church is not going to die today, or tomorrow-- Never mind. I can see you don't have the slightest idea what I'm talking about. She stalks to the bathroom, which adjoins. LOUIS follows. in and slams the door. He goes for the knob. LOUIS
Rachel--! SOUND: CLICK OF THE LOCK. LOUIS stares at the door, bewildered and upset.
Here comes a big Orinco truck, droning along, headlights
The headlights of the truck illuminate the room and we se and RACHEL asleep, each as far over to his/her own side a can get, with a big empty space in the middle. Lights and TRUCK SOUNDS slowly fade.

Cheerful little clots of scrambled eggs are scattered all across the tray of his high-chair--it looks a little like the Pacific islands done by a guy who only had a yellow c Now he scoops up a handful and throws them.
Splat! Eggs on the serving plate of toast. ELLIE
Yee-uck! Gross!

RACHEL is at the sink, doing dishes (we see the blackboar its message near her). LOUIS comes in, wearing a sport-coat and slacks, ready fo first day on the job...and ELLIE is in a pretty first day school dress. LOUIS
He can't help it, babe. Emily Post is going to be beyond him for a few years.
Here is the cat-carrier with CHURCH inside it. He waows u

location: THE KITCHEN TABLE, WITH ELLIE AND GAGE

text: ELLIE gets down and goes across to the cat-carrier. ELLIE
I don't want him to get his nuts cut, daddy! What if he dies?

location: RACHEL AND LOUIS, BY THE SINK

text: LOUIS looks shocked and amused by ELLIE'S colorful choice words. LOUIS
Good God! Where'd you hear that?
ELLIE
Missy Dandridge. And she says it's a operation!

location: RACHEL AND LOUIS, BY THE SINK

text: LOUIS tries to kiss RACHEL'S mouth. She turns her head sl he gets her cheek instead. She's still mad. LOUIS'S amuse dies. RACHEL
Honey, Church will be fine.
ELLIE
But what if he dies and has to go to the Pet Sematary?

location: LOUIS AND RACHEL, BY THE SINK

text: She gives him a look as if to say: "There! Now do you und what you did?" RACHEL
Don't be silly. Church is not going to die. LOUIS

According to what Mr. Crandall says, the road's a lot more dangerous than the operation. Church will be just the same. Well--almost the same--and we won't have to worry about him getting turned into catburgers by one of those damn Orinco trucks. At this RACHEL tightens up still more in that funny way-- actually angered by LOUIS'S reference to catburgers--but anger we sense she is deeply shocked, as a prudish woman shocked by a dirty joke. For RACHEL, that's just what dea RACHEL
That's enough of that kind of talk! LOUIS
I just said-- RACHEL
I know what you just said. Ellie, clear your place. ELLIE goes slowly back to the table. ELLIE (sets the plate down)
I'm scared. What if school here isn't like in Chicago! I'm scared and I want to go h-h-home! ELLIE bursts into loud tears and puts her hands over her
THE CAMERA FOLLOWS as they go to the table to comfort ELL RACHEL
You'll be fine, Ellie. Now you can be excused. Go and wash your face. LOUIS
And Church will be fine. ELLIE (anxious)
Do you promise, Daddy? LOUIS
Well, honey...you know that... RACHEL
Don't shilly-shally, Louis. Give the little girl her promise. LOUIS (reluctantly)
Church will be fine. I promise. ELLIE
Yayyyy! She runs off, cheered up. And RACHEL is cheered up, too. RACHEL
Thank you, Louis. LOUIS

Oh, you're welcome. Only if some- thing should go wrong while he's under the gas--it's a one-in-a-thousand shot, but it happens--you explain to her. He gets up and leaves the table. She looks after him, stu a little frightened.
GAGE (conversationally)
Here, Durch! He picks up a large glob of scrambled eggs from his tray throws it in the direction of the cat-carrier.
CHURCH is close to the mesh, looking out. Scrambled eggs mesh, driving him back, surprised.
The school bus pulls up, red lights flashing. ELLIE runs across the lawn, with her lunch-box.

location: LOUIS, RACHEL, AND GAGE, IN THE FRONT DOORWAY

text: RACHEL
Have a great day! LOUIS grabs GAGE'S hand and makes him wave it. GAGE
Bye-bye!
ELLIE climbs aboard. The red flashers go out and the bus away.

The station wagon is parked there. LOUIS comes out with a briefcase in one hand and the cat-carrier in the other. H the wagon's doorgate. A small car turns into the CREED driveway and parks besid A rather sour-looking middle-aged woman gets out and cros front of her car. Her color is bad. This is MISSY DANDRID looks at the cat-carrier. MISSY
Gonna get his-- LOUIS
--nuts cut, yes. Thank you, Missy, for introducing that colorful phrase into my daughter's vocabulary. MISSY

Don't mention it. She opens the passenger side door of her car and we see a pile of folded sheets. She reaches for them, then winces presses her hands against her midriff for a moment, as if attack of indigestion. LOUIS (sees this)
How's that belly-ache of yours? MISSY (gets the sheets)
No better and no worse. LOUIS
You ought to see a doctor about it. MISSY
It'll pass. They always do. She starts toward the house with the sheets.
RACHEL hurries past MISSY, who turns to look and then goe the house. LOUIS has just put the cat-carrier into the ba wagon and closed the doorgate as RACHEL reaches him. RACHEL (anxious)
Still friends, doc? LOUIS appears to consider this seriously for a moment...a he smiles and hugs her. They kiss. RACHEL
Thank God. I was a little worried there. Have a great first day at school, doc. No broken bones. LOUIS (smiles)
Not so much as a sprain.

head_text.subj: EXT. VICTOR PASCOW AND FRIENDS MORNING

text: PASCOW is in a blanket that is being carried by three boy girl. They are all yelling at each other not to joggle hi drop him. A small knot of horrified college kids moves wi bearers. PASCOW'S head is upside down to the CAMERA, which retreat of the advancing students. Fixed eyes stare. Half of his been shattered inward. Before the catastrophe he was a hu of about twenty. He's dressed in a U of M muscle shirt an jogging shorts. THE CAMERA PULLS JERKILY TO ONE SIDE, allowing the bearer mount the steps of a brick building. The infirmary. The l break to either side. The infirmary doors open.
She's the head nurse, a tough old babe of about fifty. CHARLTON
Holy Jesus. (turns)
Steve! Steve! Dr. Creed! Dr. Creed, we've got a mess here! Stat! The bearers sweep past her and inside, leaving a red smea blood across the midriff of MARCY CHARLTON'S uniform.

THE CAMERA will show us all we need to see, but its movem seem almost random; this is like being in the hotel kitch Sirhan shot Bobby. As the students bring in PASCOW, LOUIS comes running, fol STEVE MASTERTON, his P.A. Standing to one side are two st nurses in candystriper uniforms. They're boggled and horr LOUIS kneels. THE CAMERA RUSHES FORWARD, shoving between  onlookers. LOUIS looks at the wound. There's shattered bo pulsing brain tissue beneath. There's a scream; the girl who was carrying one corner of blanket is having hysterics. GIRL
Vic! Vic! Oh Christ! Vic! LOUIS (to CHARLTON)
Get her out. Get them all out. CHARLTON puts her arms around the girl. GIRL (struggling)

No! No! He can't die! He can't die! THE CAMERA MOVES BACK DOWN as LOUIS takes an opthalmascop STEVE and shines it in PASCOW'S bulging, fixed eyes. CHARLTON is just pushing the last of them gawkers and bea the door. LOUIS
Steve, get the ambulance over here right now. He's got to go to EMMC. STEVE
The ambulance is at Sonny's Sunoco downtown, getting-- LOUIS

--a new muffler, oh shit-- PASCOW makes a weird gargling noise. Blood suddenly spurt his mouth. He begins to seizure. One of the candystripers shrieks. THE CAMERA JERKS UP TO student nurses. One turns and throws up on the wall. CHARLTON rushes over. CANDYSTRIPER
I can't look at it...I can't stand it... CHARLTON (slaps her)

Yes you by God can. Go get the hard stretcher! As they start away, one helping the other down the hall, CHARLTON starts over to where PASCOW lies dying on his bl THE CAMERA DROPS TO LOUIS AND STEVE. LOUIS
Help me hold him. They hold PASCOW'S spasming body. STEVE
It wouldn't matter if we did have the ambulance. LOUIS
It wouldn't matter if we had the SST. PASCOW begins to quiet. LOUIS
He's going. Steve, go call the motor- pool. Marcy, roll out the crash wagon. CHARLTON
It won't-- LOUIS
I know it won't! But let's for God's sake do it by the rules! She leaves. LOUIS is alone with PASCOW. CHARLTON has draw drapes, so the doctor and the dying man have complete if privacy.
LOIS

There wasn't even supposed to be a sprain today, my friend--that's what I told her. PASCOW'S fixed eyes suddenly roll and his left hand bear- LOUIS'S right wrist. The dying man pulls him slowly but  relentlessly down, until their faces are only inches apar PASCOW
...Pet Sematary... LOUIS recoils, breaking the grip of the hand...but he can snap the grip of those bright dying eyes. Blood leaks fro PASCOW'S mouth. LOUIS (whispers)
W-What did you say...? PASCOW struggles hard to speak again. At first he can onl PASCOW
It's not the real cemetery... (Long pause) The soil of a man's heart is stonier, Louis...a man grows what he can...and tends it. LOUIS leans forward again, terrified, yet needing to know LOUIS
How do you know my name? PASCOW (gurgling)
I'll come...to you. LOUIS grabs PASCOW'S bloody shoulder. LOUIS (low but urgent)
Dammit, how do you know my name?

location: HALLWAY ENTRANCE TO RECEPTION, WITH STEVE

text: STEVE
Louis, they're sending a--
PASCOW begins to spasm again. LOUIS (snaps)
Help me! PASCOW spews more blood as STEVE kneels beside LOUIS.
CHARLTON is pushing along your basic MEDCU goodie-cart, c with emergency life-saving gear.
PASCOW'S spasms are weakening. LOUIS (to CHARLTON)
Never mind. He's going. PASCOW'S hand comes up and paws at LOUIS'S shirt, leaving handprint. Then it falls limply back. PASCOW is dead. LOUIS
Steve, will you get a sheet to cover him with? STEVE leaves the frame and LOUIS stares fixedly down at t of VICTOR PASCOW. He closes the eyes.

head_text.subj: EXT. A COUNTRY ROAD, LATE AFTERNOON

text: It's the leading edge of Maine fall, sunny and wonderful. comes LOUIS'S station wagon. As it reaches THE CAMERA, it to TRACK. RADIO (voice-over)
Tragedy struck on the first day of the University of Maine's fall semester  when Victor Pascow, a nineteen-year-old sophomore--
He still looks shocked by the tragedy. The dying man's bl handprint is partly visible on LOUIS'S shirt in spite of sport-coat. LOUIS abruptly turns off the radio and swerves over to th the road.
IT comes to a slueing, shuddering stop, almost going in t
LOUIS
He said my name. I heard it. He said my name. He stares blankly through the windshield.
All lights are off. It's late.

LOUIS and RACHEL are asleep, each on his/her own side of double. THE CAMERA MOVES IN ON LOUIS. SOUND: Loud, hollow BANG. It's very loud--loud enough to dead. LOUIS sits up. Beside him, RACHEL sleeps on. LOUIS'S eyes terror as he stares at:
He's exquisitely dead. Now pallid as well as smashed up. PASCOW
Come on, doc. We got places to go.
He is in terror...but he is also in a state of near-tranc
PASCOW
Come on, doc--don't make me tell you twice.

He glances at RACHEL. Although PASCOW has spoken in a fai voice--and the opening door was like a bomb--she's still asleep. LOUIS looks back toward PASCOW...and then gets ou He's naked except for a pair of pajama bottoms.
He turns and leaves the doorway.
He reaches the bedroom doorway himself and looks back at:
RACHEL is sleeping as before, and LOUIS himself is also i asleep, although his rest is uneasy...as if he's having a dream.
LOUIS (relieved)
Oh. Thank God. PASCOW (Voice)
Hurry up, doc.
LOUIS enters and crosses toward the door which gives on t shed/garage. This door stands open. LOUIS pauses by it. PASCOW (low)
Come on, doc... LOUIS goes into:

The station wagon is a dark hulk. LOUIS crosses to it and perplexed. PASCOW looms softly behind him and puts an arm around him turns... and suddenly his face is less than an inch from mutilated face. PASCOW
Let's go, doc. LOUIS (moans)
I don't like this dream. PASCOW
Who said you were dreaming? He begins to move toward the garage door. After a moment follows him.

head_text.subj: EXT. THE FIELD BEHIND THE HOUSE, LONG NIGHT

text: We can see two shapes moving up the path toward the woods and, behind him, LOUIS.
CAMERA HOLDS, THEN PANS DOWN as LOUIS passes under the ar
He looks around, obviously afraid.
We can see why. By starlight this is one scary place.
He suddenly sees something else, and now his fear is clos terror.
The face is back in the tumbled branches. It yawns and sn
He walks toward the deadfall as if hypnotized. PASCOW'S h on his shoulder. LOUIS turns, terrified.
He really is a dreadful mangled mess. PASCOW
This is the place where the dead speak.
He closes his eyes. LOUIS
I want to wake up. I want to wake up, that's all. I--
PASCOW
The door must not be opened. The barrier must not be crossed. Don't go on, doc. No matter how much you feel you have to. There's more power here than you know. He points at:

That grinning face--and perhaps now there are other effec well, subtle but there? Dim red light? A misty smoke drif through the tumbled dead branches? The director will know After a moment there is a HUGE GRUNTING ROAR from the woo the deadfall--it sounds like no animal we've ever heard b There is the sound of something huge shifting and snappin like a toothpick.
LOUIS has crumbled to PASCOW'S feet. His eyes are squeeze shut. LOUIS
Please, I want to wake up. Leave me  alone. It's not my fault you died; you  were as good as dead when they brought you in-- PASCOW
The power of this place is old and always restless. Sometimes the dead do more than speak. Remember, doc. CAMERA BEGINS MOVING SLOWLY IN ON LOUIS. LOUIS
Leave me alone! PASCOW
Remember. CAMERA IS TIGHT ON LOUIS. RADIO (voice)

--another beautiful day in Maine! This is Michael O'Hara sayin' that the git-go ain't gonna be that bad. Temps are going all the way up to 70... We got the Ramones for Ludlow...here's "Sheena." As the Ramones start blasting "Sheena Is A Punk Rocker":

His eyes snap open. He's in his own bedroom. As he sits u CAMERA ANGLE WIDENS OUT so we can see that he's in bed al covers on RACHEL'S side are thrown back. After the initial confusion and fear, LOUIS looks deeply he looks the way I suppose we all look upon waking up and realizing our worst dreams were only dreams after all. RACHEL (calls)
You up, doc? LOUIS
Getting there. RACHEL
I got eggs down here! LOUIS
Good d-- He throws the covers back and freezes.
They are covered with mud and pine needles. The sheets ar with woods-muck.
Utter terror.
LOUIS'S hands enter the shot and dump a bundle of sheets chute.

He's naked but for a towel around his waist. He's obvious from the shower. He starts down to the bedroom to dress. BLACK. And on it a third title card: CHURCH. Over this the SOUND of a RINGING TELEPHONE. LOUIS (voice)
Hello?

head_text.subj: INT. THE CREED LIVING ROOM AFTERNOON

text: There's a bowling match on TV. LOUIS, dressed in his Satu afternoon grubs (jeans and a Maine sweatshirt), has the p his ear. JUD CRANDALL (phone filter)
Louis? 'Fraid you may have a spot of trouble. LOUIS (frowning)
Jud? What trouble?

location: THE CRANDALL LIVING ROOM, WITH JUD

text: He's on the phone, looking out his window. JUD
Did you tell me Rachel took the kids back to Chicago for a few days?

location: THE CREED LIVING ROOM, WITH LOUIS

text: LOUIS
For Ellie's birthday, yes. I didn't go because her old man thinks I'm a shit and the feeling is heartily re- ciprocated...they'll be back tomorrow night. Jud, what's this about?

location: THE CRANDALL LIVING ROOM, WITH JUD

text: JUD
Well, there's a dead cat over here on the edge of my lawn, Louis. I think it might be your daughter's.

location: THE CREED LIVING ROOM, WITH LOUIS

text: LOUIS
Church? Oh. Oh, Jesus.

We're looking across from the CREED lawn. LOUIS waits for those trucks to go blasting by and then crosses. It's col windy. Downed autumn leaves fly. LOUIS and JUD stand over a small furry body like mourners JUD (voice)
Well?

It's lying on its belly and doesn't look much damaged. Ha LOUIS'S--come into the frame. He puts one hand under the head and lifts it so the open eyes, now a dull green, sta THE CAMERA. There's some blood on its ruff. That's all.

location: LOUIS AND JUD, ON THE EDGE OF THE CRANDALL LAWN

text: LOUIS
It's Church. JUD
I'm sorry. At least it don't look like he suffered. LOUIS

Ellie will, though. She'll suffer plenty. From his jacket pocket he takes a green plastic garbage b hands it to JUD. JUD holds the bag's mouth open on the gr while LOUIS kind of shoves the body in. During this: JUD
Loved that cat pretty well, didn't she? LOUIS
Yes. LOUIS twists the bag shut and puts one of those plastic t it. Then he holds it up. LOUIS
Bagged cat. What a mess. JUD
You going to bury him in the Pet Sematary? LOUIS (a little bitter)
I guess that's what it's there for, huh? During all of this JUD has grown peculiarly intense. JUD
Going to tell Ellie? LOUIS
I don't know. JUD
Seems like you told me about a promise you made--

GAGE is in his high chair. ELLIE, in her first-day-of-sch dress, is in her place. LOUIS is sitting at his own place hypnotized, at the middle of the table, where there is a serving dish. On the dish is scrambled eggs, strips of ba CHURCH'S corpse--staring eyes, bloody ruff and all. RACHEL (impatiently)
Don't shilly-shally, Louis. Give the little girl her promise.

location: THE CRANDALL LAWN, WITH JUD AND LOUIS

text: LOUIS (defensive)

That was a mistake. But Rachel... she doesn't like to talk about death, or even think of it. Her younger sister died of spinal meningitis when Rachel was eight. Rachel was there when it happened. Alone. I guess you could say it made a complex. JUD
Cat's just as dead, Louis. LOUIS (snaps)
Well that's a big help! (Pause) I'm sorry, Jud. JUD
No need to apologize. LOUIS
Maybe when they call I'll just tell Ellie I haven't seen the damn cat around. You know? JUD (after a long pause)
Maybe there's a better way.

location: THE START OF THE PATH TO THE PET SEMATARY, LONG EV

text: LOUIS and JUD cross the road from the CRANDALL side. LOUI carrying the plastic bag in one hand and a flashlight in other. JUD has a pick and shovel in one hand and a flashl his own in the other. Evening shadows have grown long. It's maybe an hour until JUD and LOUIS stop near the replaced tire-swing.
JUD has a Walkman clipped to the belt of his pants and ea slung around his neck. LOUIS
Jud, this is crazy. It's going to be almost dark before we get back. JUD
It's going to be dark before we even get where we're going, Louis. But we can do it...and we're going to. LOUIS
But-- JUD
Does she love the cat? LOUIS
Yes, but-- JUD

Then come on. He puts the earphones on, effectively forestalling furthe argument, and pushes the PLAY button on the Walkman. We c Marshall Crenshaw singing "Crystal Girl." JUD starts away moment, LOUIS follows.

head_text.subj: EXT. THE PET SEMATARY AND THE BACK OF THE ARCH LATE EVE

text: The SOUND of crickets...ree-ree-ree... The SOUND of footfalls. Faintly, the SOUND of Huey Lewis and the News, singing "W For A Living." It's now almost twilight. JUD and LOUIS enter the Pet Sematary. LOUIS is looking ar curiously. LOUIS
Well, folks, here we are, in Louis Creed Dreamland. JUD snaps off the Walkman and puts the earphones around h again. JUD
What say, Louis? LOUIS
Nothing. (Pause) Do we plant him on the outer circle or start a new one? JUD
We're still not where we're going. He walks past LOUIS and toward the deadfall. LOUIS follow LOUIS
What do you mean? JUD
The place we're going is on the other side of that. He points at the deadfall. LOUIS
We can't climb over that. We'll break our necks! JUD

No. We won't. I have climbed it a time or two before, and I know all the places to step. Just follow me...move easy...don't look down...and don't stop. If you stop, you'll crash through for sure. LOUIS
I'm not climbing that. JUD
Give me the cat. I'll take care of it myself. He holds out his hand and LOUIS sees the old man means ex he says. After a moment he says: LOUIS
Let's go. JUD starts up one side of the deadfall, and in spite of i snarled tangles, he mounts as easily as a man climbing a stairs. After a few second, LOUIS follows. LOUIS (low)
Thank God my Blue Cross is paid up.
First JUD'S pass THE CAMERA, then LOUIS'S, partly obscure swinging cat-bag. Their feet unerringly find the right br and just as unerringly miss holes which look like ankle-b
He's grinning, exhilarated. LOUIS
God, this is amazing!
There are beads of sweat on the old man's face. He looks stern and a little scared. JUD
Just don't stop and--
He looks down.
A dead branch snaps under one of them like a gunshot and plunges down maybe six inches.
He lurches to the edge of balance, then regains it. LOUIS
And don't look down. Right. He continues.
JUD reaches the top and starts down the far side. LOUIS r the top.
LOUIS (amazed)
Holy...!

In the dying glow of twilight, this should be a mystic, a inspiring shot. There's no more scrub underbrush and junk and juniper-bracken here; ancient firs rise almost like S The sunset light shafts among them. This is a real forest old forest. And winding upward among the trees along that carpeted floor, clearly marked by large white stones, the goes on.
He's stopped on top of the deadfall, still surveying all frank amazement.
JUD (turns to look)
Come on, Louis--don't stop!
LOUIS (grinning)
I'm all right! I'm f--
One of the branches snaps. LOUIS'S foot plunges. His cuff
We're looking up at a fairly steep angle as LOUIS stagger balance. He steps with his other foot, misses, and goes f
He does a half-somersault in the air and hits the deadfal back, the green garbage bag flying out of his hand. His f also goes. Branches crack. White dust puffs out from unde

location: JUD, AT THE BASE OF THE DEADFALL

text: LOUIS thumps to the ground nearby. JUD kneels beside him. JUD
Louis! You all right? LOUIS sits up groggily. His pants are torn. His sweatshir torn. His ankle is bleeding. LOUIS (dazed)
Sure. I guess I just lost my happy  thoughts for a second there. LOUIS gets slowly up and retrieves the bag, which is rath shredded now--and we can see catfur through some of the r LOUIS (continues)
I shouldn't have stopped...and it does bite. He whaps the flashlight against his palm a time or two an light comes on. Satisfied, he shuts it off. JUD
No, you shouldn't have stopped. But you got away with it. Important thing is are you sure you're all right? LOUIS
Yes. (Pause) Where are we going, Jud? JUD
You'll see before long. Let's go. He starts off up the path. After a moment LOUIS follows, the bag.

location: LOUIS AND JUD, FROM THE DEADFALL

text: Again, there should be a sense of awe and mystery as they tolling up the path into the twilight, dwarfed by those a firs. SOUND OF CRICKETS, LOW at first, then UP TO LOUD: Ree-ree

location: LOUIS AND JUD, AT THE EDGE OF LITTLE GOD SWAMP TWI

text: Lots of undergrowth here, and creeping ground-mist, too. OF CRICKETS is now only a part of the soundtrack: BUZZ OF THUMP OF FROGS. Swamp-sounds. LOUIS looks frankly doubtful. JUD
This next bit's like the deadfall, Louis-- you got to walk steady and easy. Just follow me and don't look down.

Mysterious...awesome...scary. Dead trees poke out of the twisted hands. There's scummy water standing around tusso covered with long grass, most of it dead. There's a lot o underbrush. All of this fades away into a grim, obscuring fog.
JUD
Micmacs used to call it Little God Swamp. LOUIS
Is there quicksand? JUD
Ayuh. LOUIS (nervous; joking)
Are there ghosts? JUD looks at him expressionlessly. JUD
Ayuh. JUD starts off, stepping to the first tussock. After a mo LOUIS follows.
His face is set, strange. JUD
There's a lot of funny things down this way, Louis.
LOUIS
You're telling me.
JUD (still walking)
The air's heavier...more electrical... something. You might see St. Elmo's Fire...what the sailors call 'foo-lights.' It makes funny shapes, but it's nothing.
HE looks up and his eyes widen as he sees:
A faintly glowing, ethereal shape hangs in the branches o the dead trees. It looks a bit like a corpse. In fact, I looks quite a bit like PASCOW'S corpse. As we watch it fades...fades...is gone.
He's somewhere between being mystified and puzzled and be scared. Now a weakly glowing fireball rolls slowly across surface of the standing water toward him...and then just into the thick mist. LOUIS
It's funny, all right.
JUD
Just don't stop, Louis. You don't ever want to stop down here in Little God. (Pause) And you don't ever want to look behind you, whatever you hear.
We see them moving through the mist like wraiths, JUD wit digging tools, LOUIS with his light and his Hefty-Bag cof whole swamp is glowing dimly.

head_text.subj: EXT. THE FAR SIDE OF LITTLE GOD SWAMP NIGHT

text: In the extreme f.g. we can see firm ground sloping up. Ah thick white mist. And here comes JUD and LOUIS slogging t and out of it. Both of them are wet from the knees down. into the woods on the far side.

location: A LOW, STONY BLUFF OR STEEP HILL

text: In the book this is described as being almost a cliff, bu hill rising out of the woods would serve just as well. We steps cut into the side, and two figures--LOUIS and JUD-- up them.
JUD'S panting and out of breath; LOUIS is, if anything, i shape. JUD
Almost there, Louis. LOUIS
You keep saying that. JUD
This time I mean it. He tops the last step and stands on a rocky level under t the wind blowing his hair off his deeply lined brow. A fe later LOUIS joins him and stares with undisguised wonder.

The top of this hill or bluff is rocky and bare, but ther number of rocky piles. But for every pile of rocks we can there are ten littered heaps, as if the neat piles had be apart. There's a shape to all of this, and it is the shap Pet Sematary: concentric circles. SOUND: The wind, blowing ceaselessly.

location: LOUIS AND JUD, AT THE EDGE OF THE BURYING GROUND

text: LOUIS (awed)
What is this place? JUD
This was their burying ground, Louis. LOUIS
Whose burying ground? JUD
The Micmac Indians. I brought you here to bury Ellen's cat. LOUIS
Why? For God's sake, why? JUD
I had my reasons, Louis. We'll talk later. All right? LOUIS
I guess so...but... JUD
You want to rest a bit before you start? LOUIS
No, I'm okay. Will I really be able to dig him a grave? The soil looks thin. JUD
Soil's thin, all right. But you'll manage. He hands him the pick and shovel. JUD

I'm going to sit over yonder and have a smoke. I'd help you, but you've got to do it yourself. Each buries his own. That's how it was done then. JUD walks away, leaving LOUIS with the digging tools in o and the flashlight in the other. After a minute, LOUIS wa into the burying ground.

text: SOUND: The wind. It blows ceaselessly up here. The hole's about two and a half feet deep. Stubby rocks p from the sides. The pick comes down, hits a rock at the b and flashes fire.
He drops the pick and sticks his hurt hands in his armpit him we see a low pile of rocks and earth. JUD (voice)
Should be deep enough. He joins LOUIS. He's got a lot of rocks in his arms. LOUIS
You think so? He notices the rocks. LOUIS
What are those for? JUD
Your cairn.
Those tumbled piles of rock are very obvious.

location: LOUIS AND JUD, BY CHURCH'S GRAVE

text: LOUIS
Doesn't look like they last long. JUD
Don't worry about that. LOUIS
Jud, why am I doing all this? JUD
Because it's right. He walks off again. LOUIS looks after him for a moment, then kneels down.
He opens it and looks in at CHURCH'S stiffening corpse. LOUIS

Pax vobiscum, Church old buddy. You were a hell of a god cat. I doubt if you were worth all this aggravation, but you were a hell of a good cat. He tumbles the bag containing the body into the grave, an begins pushing the stony soil over it with the spade.
LOUIS'S hands come into the frame and add a final two or stones.
He looks at it for a moment and stands up. JUD is right t JUD
That's fine. You did real good. LOUIS looks at him.
There's a light on in the kitchen, but that's all. There' at first, and then the PHONE STARTS RINGING.
LOUIS and JUD are coming down the path with their tools a lights. They are both clearly fagged out. SOUND, FAINT: The telephone. LOUIS
Oh, shit! Rachel! He drops the tools and sprints.

text: LOUIS runs into the side yard. SOUND of the phone is loud

text: He runs to the door and inside.

text: He stands there, eyes inscrutable.
