text: It stops. A beat later LOUIS enters the room. He picks it although he already knows it's too late. He listens to th of the dial tone and then drops it back into the cradle,  disgusted. He starts to dial a number from memory. JUD (voice)
Louis.

location: THE KITCHEN/LIVING ROOM DOORWAY, WITH JUD

text: JUD
When you talk to 'em, not one word about what we done tonight. 'S'far's you know, the cat's still fine.
After a moment he lowers it into the cradle.
JUD

You'll understand. In the meantime, keep your peace. What we did, Louis, was a secret thing. Women are supposed to be the ones who are good at keeping secrets, but any woman who knows anything at all would tell you she's never seen into a man's heart. The soil of a man's heart is stonier, Louis--like the soil up there in the old Micmac burying ground. A man grows what he can...and tends it. During this, he's come across the room to LOUIS and dropp hand on LOUIS'S shoulder. LOUIS
But-- JUD

No buts! Accept what's done, Louis. What we done was right. Another time it might not be, but tonight it was... at least I hope to Christ it was. Now you make your call...but not a word about tonight.
SOUNDS: Boops and beeps of a touch-tone telephone. Ringin DORY GOLDMAN (voice)
Goldman residence. LOUIS

Hi, Dory...it's Louis-- During this, another SOUND has been growing: an approachi As JUD gains his side of the road, he looks back, and we on his face--no matter what he said to LOUIS, he's sorry tonight's piece of work. A moment later a highballing Orinco truck cuts between TH and JUD.

head_text.subj: INT. LOUIS, IN THE LIVING ROOM NIGHT

text: He's on the phone, smiling and happy. RACHEL (voice)
You want to talk to the birthday girl? LOUIS
That'd be real fine. ELLIE (voice)
Hi...daddy? LOUIS (sings)
Happy birthday to you/Happy birthday to you/Happy birthday, dear Ellie/Happy birthday to you! ELLIE (voice)
That was awful, daddy. LOUIS
Yeah, I know...how are things out  there in Chicagoland? ELLIE
Fine...except when Mom was airing Gage's diaper rash, he walked away and got into Grampa's study and pooped in Grampa's favorite chair. LOUIS (grinning broadly)
Way to go, Gage! ELLIE (voice)
What? LOUIS
I said that's too bad. What did you get for presents from Gramma and Grampa? ELLIE (voice)
Lots of stuff! I got two dresses...and a Chatty Cathy doll...

location: THE GOLDMAN LIVING ROOM, WITH ELLIE

text: She's dressed for bed, in fuzzy pink pajamas. Her Chatty crooked in one arm. In her lap is a Garfield transistor r ELLIE
...and a Garfield radio! How's Church, dad? Does he miss me?

location: THE CREED LIVING ROOM, WITH LOUIS

text: The smile fades off his face. It's replaced with a look o combined guilt and unhappiness. He's looking at his hands are still dark with the dirt from CHURCH'S grave. LOUIS
Well...I guess he's just fine, Ellie. I haven't seen him this evening, but--

location: THE GOLDMAN LIVING ROOM, WITH ELLIE

text: RACHEL, holding GAGE, sits on the arm of ELLIE'S chair. ELLIE
Well, make sure you put him down cellar before you go to bed so he can't run out in the road and get greased. And kiss him goodnight for me. LOUIS (voice)
Yuck! Kiss your own cat! ELLIE
Want to talk to Gage? Before he can answer, she puts the phone in GAGE'S hand. RACHEL watch, amused, as GAGE gobbles into it. Perhaps RA encourages him to say a few words.

location: THE CREED LVING ROOM, WITH LOUIS

text: From the telephone comes the sound of GAGE talking and ch LOUIS is not listening. His eyes--and his mind--are far a
LOUIS is raking leaves on the side lawn, near the tree wi tire swing. After a moment or two of this he props the ra against the tree and starts toward the garage. He goes in
It's dim in here. LOUIS is crossing to the door which com to the kitchen. As he passes the station wagon, he hears HISS. He turns.
He's on top of the car, but at this point we probably don notice; THE CAMERA is so close that CHURCH looks like he' right down our throats. He's hissing angrily.
He recoils and stumbles backward with a cry. He hits a to on the wall and a lot of them fall down with a LOUD JANGL NOISE.

location: ON TOP OF THE STATION WAGON, WITH CHURCH

text: He jumps down, frightened by the noise, and the CAMERA TR he goes flying out the garage door into the sunlight.
He gets slowly to his feet again. He's getting over his f we can see he's totally freaked out by what gave him that He goes to the garage door and looks out. LOUIS (calls)
Church?
Grass and fallen leaves. No sign of CHURCH.

He's spooning cat-food into a dish. He goes to the door-- should be a total of three doors in the kitchen: one to t room, one to the shed/garage, and one which leads directl outside. LOUIS uses this latter door now.
He puts the dish of food down and sits beside it. LOUIS
Food, Church...food! SOUND: Miaow.
CHURCH comes slinking out of the bushes and comes slowly THE CAMERA. He stops, looking mistrustful.
LOUIS
Come on, Church! Chow down!
He crosses to the stoop and begins eating the food. LOUIS (to himself)
Christ. I don't believe this. He picks CHURCH up. CHURCH miaows again--he wants the foo LOUIS (wincing)
God, you stink, Church. CHURCH is looking at the food, trying to get out of LOUIS LOUIS
In a second. He tilts the cat's head back so he can get a look at CHUR neck.
There's some sort of mark here--a clear remnant        of line of white fur, or perhaps a dark red scar where no fu grows.

location: LOUIS AND CHURCH, ON THE STOOP

text: LOUIS sees something else as he lets the cat's neck go. H something out of CHURCH'S whiskers.
It's a shred of green plastic.
LOUIS
Chewed his way out. Jesus Baldheaded Christ, he ch-- CHURCH suddenly claws at his face. LOUIS
Ow! He claps his hand to his face. CHURCH leaps for the food. slowly takes his hand away. There are claw marks on his c welling blood. He looks at the cat.

The garden is a plot of about half an acre. JUD comes tru slowly along a row, pushing a wheelbarrow. There are seve pumpkins in it. JUD is wearing old khaki gardening pants Ramones sweatshirt. He's wearing his headphones and we ca the Romantics doing "What I Like About You." JUD is singi and bopping a little--as much as his arthritis will allow can dig it. He sees a real big pumpkin, stops, and bends over to get He takes out his pocket-knife and slits the pumpkin-vine. the pumpkin in his arms and stands up. He turns...and LOU right there (kind of a cheap jump, but always fun), looki totally stunned. JUD, startled, drops the pumpkin. LOUIS reaches out and s phones off JUD'S ears. LOUIS
What did we do?
LOUIS is sitting at the kitchen table. JUD is at the frid comes back with a couple of long-necked bottles of beer a them. JUD
I most generally don't start before noon, but this looks like an exception. LOUIS
What did we do, Jud? JUD
Why, saved a little girl from being unhappy...that's all. Drink up, Louis! LOUIS drinks about half the beer. LOUIS
I tried to tell myself I buried him alive. You know--Edgar Allan Poe meets Felix the Cat. But... JUD
Wouldn't wash? LOUIS
No. I'm a doctor. I know death when I see it, and Church was dead. He smells horrible and he uses his claws, but he's alive...and I feel like I'm going crazy. It was that place, wasn't it? JUD
Ayuh. It was the rag-man told me about the place--Stanley Bouchard. Us kids just called him Stanny B. He was half Micmac himself. LOUIS drains his beer. LOUIS
Can I have another one? JUD
I guess it wouldn't hurt. He gets up and goes to the fridge.
JUD
The Micmacs used to bury their dead up there long before the whites came. He returns to the table with the beer. JUD
They buried their dead and for a long time their dead stayed buried. Then something happened. Half the tribe died in a season. The rest moved on. They said a Wendigo had soured the ground. LOUIS
Wendigo? JUD

Spirit of the north country. Not a good spirit. Wendigos are great liars and tricksters, according to the stories.  And if one touches you... JUD pauses, perhaps a flustered, and gathers his thoughts JUD

Maybe it really was a Wendigo-- I ain't the one to say it wasn't-- or maybe it was just some disease. Whatever the reason, those that were left moved on. But they left that place...the way it is now. JUD shrugs, and drinks.

head_text.subj: EXT. JUD AS A BOY, CU/SEPIA TONE DAY

text: The time here is about 1910. JUD is wearing short pants. crying, not in any big-deal histrionic way, but as if he keep doing it for a long time. I mean he looks really sad JUD (voice)

I loved my dog a lot, Louis. When Spot died, I thought I was gonna die. JUD is sitting on the front stoop. It's the same house JU in now, but the porch hasn't been added yet, and the road rather than tar. Along this road comes a horse-drawn wagon--STANNY B.'S wa wagon's full of junk, rags, bottles...stuff to sell and s Strung across the top are bells, and we can hear their CH SOUND...but faint, like bells heard in a dream. STANNY B. is old and drunk. Dust spumes up behind the wag draws up to the CRANDALL house and stops. He gets down, a falls, takes a bottle out of his back pocket, drinks, and approaches JUD. We can see him speaking.

location: JUD'S KITCHEN, WITH JUD AND LOUIS

text: LOUIS
You and this old Indian rag-man-- JUD
Stanny B. did for me what I did for you last night, Louis. Only I wasn't alone when Spot came back.

head_text.subj: EXT. THE CRANDALL BACK YARD/SEPIA TONE DAY

text: JUD'S MOTHER is back to THE CAMERA, hanging sheets on the The sheets billow. And suddenly, pushing out from behind quite near her, is a small mongrel dog. SPOT. He's covere graveyard dirt. His eyes are red and rolling. He splashes sheets with the muck of his passage. JUD (voice)
My mother was with me. She sees who it is--what it is--and backs away, screaming horrified.
JUD (voice)

He'd got caught in bobwire that infected. You could still see the marks on him. And so we can, around his neck and along the side of his These marks are the counterpart of the marks we've alread CHURCH. SOUND of JUD'S MOM SCREAMING. Like the bells, these are s heard in a dream.

location: THE BACK STOOP OF THE CRANDALL HOUSE/SEPIA

text: The BOY JUD comes running out, dressed in a night-shirt.
She's cringing against the fence at the rear of the yard. stands in front of her, swaying from side to side, as if JUD'S MOM (dim; far)
Get your dog, Jud! He stinks of the ground you buried him in! Come here and get your dog! She is in utter terror.
Horrified...ashamed.
JUD'S MOM (terror)

location: JUD AND LOUIS, IN JUD'S KITCHEN

text: LOUIS

How did your mother take it, Jud? How did she take it when your dog came back from the dead? JUD'S face is a complication. He's lying to LOUIS, certai is he also lying to himself? Yes, I think so. JUD
Well, she was a little upset at first, and that's why I thought you ought to hold your peace when you talked to your people last night...you did, didn't you, Louis? LOUIS
Yes. JUD
Why, then, things should be fine. LOUIS
A little upset is all she was? Because I'll tell you, Jud, my brains feel a little like a nuclear reactor on the edge of a meltdown. JUD
She got used to the idea. Spot lived another four years. He died peacefully in the night that second time, and I buried him in the Pet Sematary...where his bones still lie.

location: THE ROAD BETWEEN THE TWO HOUSES, WITH LOUIS AND JUD

text: We see them crossing. LOUIS (voice)
You still haven't told me why you did it.

location: JUD AND LOUIS, ON THE CREED FRONT LAWN

text: JUD
A man doesn't always know why he does things, Louis. I think I did it because your daughter ain't ready for her favorite pet to die. LOUIS
What? JUD

Ellie's a little scared of death. And the main reason Ellie's that way is because your wife is a lot scared of death. Now you just go ahead and tell me I'm wrong. But LOUIS'S reaction tells him he's not wrong--in fact, J hit the nail right on the head.
LOUIS'S hands come into the frame and turn the spigots.
He starts to undress, still looking troubled. We should n that the door behind him is firmly shut. The bathroom has windows.
The hot water is steaming. LOUIS'S hands enter the frame off the faucets. SOUND of LOUIS climbing in.
A big sigh and an expression of exquisite pleasure. He re the hot water. After a few moments he puts a wet washclot his face.

location: BY THE KITCHEN SINK, WITH RACHEL

text: RACHEL
Don't shilly-shally, Louis. Give the little girl her promise.

GAGE is in his high chair. ELLIE is at her place, crying. RACHEL'S place sits VICTOR PASCOW, bloody and wrecked. LO in his place. On the platter of bacon and scrambled eggs CHURCH'S mangled body. PASCOW
The door must not be opened. The barrier must not be crossed. LOUIS
You don't understand--
The washrag is slipping, but it still covers his face. LOUIS (mutters)
--I'm a doctor.

In attendance: PASCOW, LOUIS, ELLIE, GAGE in his high cha in the middle of the table, clotted with dirt and blood, staring, neck a gory mess of infected wounds, is SPOT. He dotted with clots of scrambled egg and bits of bacon. PASCOW
Sometimes the dead do more than speak. Remember, doc.
RACHEL (with great force)
Don't shilly-shally, Louis. Promise me. Promise me. Promise me.
The washcloth has slipped enough so we can see his eyes a closed--he's dozing. LOUIS
Promise...
To LOUIS, ELLIE, PASCOW, GAGE, and the corpse of SPOT ent his eyes shocked and staring. JUD (to LOUIS)
You do it for all the best reasons, but that ain't why. You do it because it gets hold of you...you do it because you have to.

The washrag has worked its way down to his mouth by now. is deepening; he's started to snore a little. SOUND: A splash. Something has been dropped into the bath LOUIS opens his eyes. Looks puzzled. Looks down. Eyes wid shock.
A very large and very mangled dead rat floats in the bath actually brushing against LOUIS'S chest. Blood has begun the water.
Turns his head, preparatory to leaping out.
Its mouth yawns open. It hisses, showing bloodstained tee

LOUIS leaps from the tub. Grabs a towel and begins to rub frantically. He's grossed out. The cat tries to arch agai and he hits it. CHURCH falls to the floor, hissing. LOUIS looks at the closed door. LOUIS
How the hell did you get in? He may not know that, but he knows how it's going to get opens the door to the upstairs hall. If CHURCH doesn't go LOUIS helps it with his foot. Then he looks down at:
Staring at the rat. Over this: THE SOUND OF JET ENGINES.
Its landing gear unfolds preparatory to touching down at International Airport.
Lots of people making their way up the jetway.
He's looking anxiously for his people. In one hand he's g dozen roses. His face lights up.
Here comes LOUIS'S family. ELLIE is a little ahead. RACHE pushing GAGE in his stroller. ELLIE sees LOUIS and lights ELLIE
Daddy! She runs for him.
ELLIE comes belting up to LOUIS, weaving among the deplan a slalom skier. She leaps into his arms. LOUIS swings her cheerfully. LOUIS
Hi, sugar! She smacks him noisily. He smacks her back just as noisil ELLIE
Daddy, is Church all right? LOUIS'S face changes. All at once he's watchful. LOUIS
Yes...I guess so. He was sleeping on the front porch when I left. ELLIE
Cause I had a bad dream about him. I dreamed he got hit by a car and you and Mr. Crandall buried him in the Pet Sematary. LOUIS (trying to smile)
That was a silly dream, wasn't it? ELLIE
Is he really all right? LOUIS
Yes. ELLIE
Because you promised. LOUIS
I know. RACHEL reaches them. She's pretty tired. Hair hanging in good travelling clothes now looking a bit wrinkled and a stale. RACHEL
Want to take your son, doc? LOUIS does. GAGE is ecstatic. LOUIS kisses RACHEL deeply.
CHURCH at the door, waiting to be let out. ELLIE does the CHURCH oils out into the shed/garage. ELLIE closes the do looks distressed. She crosses the kitchen again.

head_text.subj: INT. THE CREED LIVING ROOM, NIGHT

text: RACHEL, in a flannel nightgown, is watching TV. LOUIS is medical tome and making notes. GAGE, zipped into a warm b suit, is sacking on the couch. ELLIE (entering)
Can cats have shampoos? RACHEL
Yes--you have to take them to someone who grooms animals, though. I think it's pretty expensive. ELLIE (still upset)
I don't care. I'll save up my allowance and pay for it. Church smells bad. LOUIS
I've noticed it, too. I'll cough up the money, Ellen. ELLIE
I hate that smell.
He looks both grim and sad--a man discovering that what y for you own, and what you own always comes home to you. LOUIS
Yes--I hate it, too. BLACK. And on it, a fourth title card: MISSY DANDRIDGE. SOUND: A pen scratching over paper.

A single sheet of lined paper is spotlighted by the glow desk-lamp. On it, MISSY'S right hand is just finishing: " Intestinal Cancer. Cannot face this Pain. Sorry." The hand puts the pen down. It tears the paper in two, le just the half with the message.
A light comes on and we see a hangman's noose strung over It dangles above a kitchen table which has been relegated cellar duty. SOUND: Descending footsteps.
SOUND of MISSY climbing onto the table. Her face enters the frame. She looks very sick. She puts into the noose and rakes it tight at the hyoid bone.
One light on...a cellar light. SOUND: Ree-ree-ree...then... SOUND: Kick! THUMP! SOUND: Ree-ree-ree...
She hangs limply, hands dangling at her sides, above the which now lies upon its side. We can see the note clearly pinned it to the bodice of her housedress. SOUND: Car engines starting up.

head_text.subj: EXT. IN FRONT OF THE GRACE METHODIST CHURCH DAY

text: People are coming out and getting into their cars and tur the headlights, even though it is only mid-morning. In the immediate f.g. is a hearse. Four pallbearers are l coffin into it.

location: LOUIS AND ELLIE, ON THE CHURCH STEPS

text: ELLIE

They're all turning on their lights! Daddy, why are they all turning on their lights in the middle of the day? JUD, dressed in a rusty old black suit and a black tie, c and stands with them. He looks haggard and old. JUD
They do it to honor the dead, Ellen. ELLIE
Is that right, dad? LOUIS
Yes. To honor the dead.
More cars start up; more lights come on; the back doors o hearse swing closed.

[NOTE: In the book LOUIS finds it difficult to enter at n because of a high iron fence. Here we should see there's problem; there's only a low stone wall between the gravey the public road.] The mourners are of course gathered around the grave of M DANDRIDGE. The coffin rests above it on runners. MINISTER (voice)
May the Lord bless you and keep you; may the Lord make his face to shine upon you, and comfort you, and lift you up, and give you peace. Amen.
As the mourners begin to break up, these three start back LOUIS'S car. JUD
Rachel not feeling well? LOUIS
Well...a touch of the flu... ELLIE
She's in bed. She was throwing up. Ever since Mrs. Rogers called and said Missy-- LOUIS
That's enough, Ellen. They've reached the CREED station wagon. JUD
Out of the mouths of babes, Louis. LOUIS
This babe has said enough. He opens the front passenger door. LOUIS
Hop in, Ellie. She does, and LOUIS closes the door. JUD

Poor Missy. God, I was sorry to hear. I remember when she was no older'n Ellen there, walking down to the store with her Raggedy Anne doll draggin' behind her in the dust. I don't know why God takes someone like her, who should have a bunch of years still in front of them, and lets an old shit like me just go on and on. LOUIS
My father used to have a saying, Jud-- "God sees the truth, but waits." JUD
Ayuh...how is your cat, Louis? LOUIS
It's Ellie's cat. JUD
Nope. He's your cat now. JUD opens one of the back doors as LOUIS goes around to t driver's side.

location: THE BACK SEAT OF THE WAGON

text: JUD has tilted over in one corner and is snoring. His Wal 'phones are on and we can hear the tinny sounds of Billy little old man's drool trickles down from one corner of h
Tears are spilling freely down ELLIE'S face. LOUIS
Ellie? What's wrong? ELLIE
No more chocolate chip cookies. LOUIS
Huh? ELLIE
Missy made the best chocolate chip cookies in the world--even Mom said so. Now there won't be any more because she's gonna be dead forever! She cries harder. LOUIS reaches out and strokes her hair.
Moving up the country road toward home through blazing fa foliage.
On it is a scene from "Night of the Living Dead." NEWSCASTER
Bizarre as it may seem, it now seems almost beyond doubt: the dead are returning to eat the living. ELLIE (voice)
Daddy?

head_text.subj: INT. THE CREED LIVING ROOM NIGHT

text: There's a VCR on top of the TV; LOUIS has been watching " Now he quickly uses the remote control to shut down the T She's dressed for bed, and comes toward him slowly. LOUIS
What's up, sugar? ELLIE
Daddy, do you think Missy Dandridge went to heaven? LOUIS
What?
She's putting away the last of the supper things. She hea and moves toward the living room door to listen. She does at all well. Her eyes are red from crying and her face is

location: THE LIVING ROOM, WITH LOUIS AND ELLIE

text: She's gotten up into his lap. ELLIE
At school Michael McDowell said she was gonna fry in hell. Michael McDowell says all sewersides fry in hell. LOUIS
Well, I think Michael McDowell is so full of shit he probably squeaks when he walks, my dear.
She smiles a little at this.

location: LOUIS AND ELLIE, IN THE LIVING ROOM

text: LOUIS
But don't you dare say that. ELLIE
I won't...is Missy in heaven, do you think? LOUIS
I don't know, honey. Different people believe all sorts of different things happen to us when we die. Some believe in heaven or hell. Some think we're born again as little children-- ELLIE
Sure, carnation. Like in that movie you rented, Audrey Rose. LOUIS
Well, it's actually reincarnation, but you get the idea. And some people think we just wink out...like a candle flame when the wind blows hard. ELLIE
Do you believe that? LOUIS looks toward:
CHURCH is sleeping.
LOUIS
I think we go on. I'm not sure what happens after we die, but yeah-- I have faith in that. ELLIE
You believe in it. LOUIS
Oh, faith's a little more than just believing.
Listening intently.
LOUIS (continues)
I'll tell you what faith is--it's the evidence of the heart; the assurance of things not seen. ELLIE
I don't get it. LOUIS
Well, here we are, sitting in my chair. Do you think my chair will be here tomorrow? ELLIE
Yeah, sure. LOUIS
Then you have faith in that. But we don't know it will be; after all, some crazed chair-burglar might break in while we're away and steal it, right? ELLIE'S giggling.
She's smiling, too...but tears are running down her cheek
LOUIS
But we plan on that chair. We believe in that chair. And I plan on going on somehow as Louis Creed, after I die. I believe I will. ELLIE (awed)
You have faith in that. LOUIS
Yes ma'am. Just like I have faith that it is now time for Ellen Creed to get ready for bed. So buzz. He gets her off his lap. ELLIE
I'm not tired! LOUIS
I'm sure you're not. ELLIE
Then why do I have to go to bed? LOUIS
Because your mother and I need the rest, sugar. Now buzz. She heads toward the stairs.
LOUIS is in bed, reading. RACHEL, wearing a robe over her nightgown, comes in. RACHEL
I heard you tonight. LOUIS
I thought maybe you did. I know you don't approve of the subject being raised-- RACHEL
That's not true. The subject scares me. Because of Zelda. LOUIS puts his book down and looks at her thoughtfully. LOUIS
Your sister, I know. RACHEL sits down on the end of the bed. She's clasping he nervously together. RACHEL

Sometimes you're so good with her, Louis--so straight with her--that you make me ashamed of myself. LOUIS sits up and scoots down the bed to her. He tries to arm around her. She rejects it--but gently. RACHEL
I'm sorry I couldn't go with you to Missy's funeral. And that I blew up when we went to that silly animal graveyard. LOUIS
That's forgotten. RACHEL
Not by me, it isn't. I know how badly I acted, how unfair I was. It's just that I..you know. LOUIS
Yes, I guess I do. He makes a place for her beside him and hugs her. They li silently together for awhile, taking comfort from each ot RACHEL
I'm going to try to do better. LOUIS
You're doing fine.
BLACK. And on it, a fifth title card: GAGE. SOUND: An idling truck motor.

head_text.subj: EXT. THE GRILLE OF A TRUCK DAY

text: It looks monstrous...as high as a mountain.
It's an Orinco tanker. The driver, a young man in khaki f and a baseball cap, climbs up into the cab. He slams the jams the truck into gear. IRWIN GOLDMAN (voice)
I knew something like this would happen.

head_text.subj: EXT. THE ORINCO SHIPPING YARD DAY

text: The truck comes rolling slowly toward the main gate...sto driver can look both ways...and then pulls slowly out ont 9. IRWIN (voice continues)
I told her when you were first married. 'You'll have all the grief you can stand, and more,' I said.

head_text.subj: INT. A FUNERAL CHAPEL, WITH IRWIN GOLDMAN AND LOUIS DAY

text: There are others here, but they are in the b.g., and conc on the scene the old man is making. He's RACHEL'S dad. LO sitting in the aisle seat of a pew-like bench. He looks t shattered--they both do, actually. He's staring at the ol if he cannot in the least comprehend what he's saying. IRWIN (continues)
And now look at this! He gestures toward:

head_text.subj: INT. THE FRONT OF THE FUNERAL CHAPEL DAY

text: Here, half-buried in floral tributes, is a child-sized co GAGE'S.
IRWIN (weeping)
Run over in the road like a...a chipmunk!
Getting up to speed.
There's a hand holding it--LOUIS'S. The kite begins to mo THE CAMERA TRACKS IT. It flaps and flutters.

location: THE FIELD BESIDE THE CREED HOUSE, WITH LOUIS

text: He runs with the kite beneath a gorgeous fall sky in whic clouds move like airy ocean liners. ELLIE (voice)
Go, daddy!
The remains of a picnic lunch are spread here. Looks like ate well. In attendance: RACHEL, ELLIE, GAGE, and JUD CRA GAGE
Go, dayee! They all laugh--JUD ruffles the kid's hair.
He's paying out string--and the kite is going up. LOUIS (voice)
Where's Rachel?

location: THE FUNERAL CHAPEL, WITH LOUIS AND IRWIN

text: IRWIN looks toward:

location: THE BACK OF THE CHAPEL, WITH RACHEL AND DORY GOLDMA

text: They are by the sign-in book. Both are dressed in black. haggard. But RACHEL looks more than haggard; she looks da insane with grief and horror.
IRWIN (leaning forward)
With her mother! Where she should be! As for you, I hope you rot in hell! In hell, do you hear me? We should; by now he's screaming his head off.

head_text.subj: INT. THE CAB OF THE ORINCO TRUCK DAY

text: The driver is whistling. A transistor radio hangs from th view mirror on a strap. He turns it on. The Ramones. "She Hey-ho, let's go.
Unrolling before us at a good clip--too good, maybe.
Stamping the pedal closer to the metal.
Belting toward THE CAMERA. SOUND of the GROWLING ENGINE.
LOUIS has clearly gotten it up okay.
He's holding the string, looking up at the sky. Now he lo at the picnic table. LOUIS
Hey, Gage!
GAGE gets down and runs toward his father.
Belting along fast. SOUND of the Ramones.

location: THE FIELD, WITH LOUIS AND GAGE

text: GAGE runs to his dad, chubby legs working. He reaches him LOUIS transfers thee ball of string to GAGE'S hands. GAGE
Dat? LOUIS
String! You're flying it, Gage--you got the hammer, my man! GAGE
Gage fline it? LOUIS
Bet your boots. Look-- LOUIS puts his hands over GAGE'S hands and pulls them dow
It dips in the sky.
LOUIS
See? GAGE
Gage fline it!! LOUIS (tenderly)
Bet your ass, little hero. He kisses his son. They look up at:
Dipping and drifting in that gorgeous fall sky. IRWIN GOLDMAN (voice)
Where were you while he was playing in the road? Thinking about your stupid medical articles? You stinking shit! You killer of children!

location: THE FUNERAL CHAPEL, WITH LOUIS AND IRWIN

text: IRWIN
You-- But there is no way he can express his outrage with mere LOUIS sits staring numbly up at him, IRWIN punches him in nose. LOUIS sprawls backward, falling out of the pew onto floor.

location: THE REAR OF THE CHAPEL, FEATURING RACHEL AND DORY

text: RACHEL screams and starts forward. DORY pulls her back. RACHEL
Louis! Daddy! Stop it! STOP IT!
LOUIS is getting up groggily. Hs nose is pouring blood. IRWIN
How do you like that, you son of a bitch? I should have done it sooner! IRWIN punches him in the stomach. LOUIS "oofs" and double
Among them we see STEVE MASTERTON and MARCY CHARLTON. STEVE (getting up)
Hey!
LOUIS is slowly straightening up. IRWIN is in a sour fren glee. IRWIN
How do you like that? How do-- LOUIS pushes the old man with both hands.
He goes stumbling and flailing backwards...strikes the co knocks it off its bier. A SCREAM goes up from the mourner
RACHEL screams. Her mother struggles to hold her but RACH breaks free and goes running down the aisle.
MARCY
Stop them. Right now. STEVE gets up and goes toward:

location: THE FRONT OF THE CHAPEL, WITH IRWIN

text: He's picking himself out of a tangled mess of coffin and  overturned floral tributes. His suit is wet from spilled He's weeping. LOUIS has just reached him, and that stunned look is gone he intends to do the Cool Jerk all over IRWIN GOLDMAN'S p little body. IRWIN strikes a Gentleman Jim Corbett pugili pose. IRWIN
Come on! I'm ready for ya! I'll take y'apart! As LOUIS wades in, STEVE MASTERTON gets between them...at possible moment. STEVE
Stop it! LOUIS swings. STEVE manages to block the punch with his b STEVE

Stop it! Jesus, what's wrong with you, Louis? It's your son's funeral, not a boxing match! That gets to LOUIS. He drops his fists. That stunned expr creeps over his face again--that look that says he doesn' the slightest clue as to what's going on or how it could have happened.
PASCOW (voice)
The soil of a man's heart is stonier, doc-- LOUIS turns toward:

location: THE FRONT PEW, WITH PASCOW AND CHURCH

text: PASCOW, bloody and ruined in his jogging shorts and muscl has the pew to himself...except for CHURCH, who is sittin lap and PURRING. PASCOW
A man grows what he can...and tends it.
A sense of horrible awareness comes into his face...and t covers it with his hands and begins to SOB. SOUND, COMING UP: A TRUCK MOTOR.
The trucker is singing along with the radio.
It's closer to the floorboards than ever.

location: LOUIS AND GAGE WITH THE KITE, IN THE FIELD

text: We are at some distance--far enough to see that the two o have moved quite close to the road.
We can see their faces upturned to us--we can hear the AM RATTLING SOUND of the kite itself. THE CAMERA PANS TO THE LEFT--to the road. And we can see truck, fairly close by now, and coming closer.

location: THE PICNIC TABLE, WITH RACHEL, ELLIE, AND JUD

text: JUD'S lighting a cigarette. His Walkman 'phones are aroun neck. ELLIE
I want to fly it! Can I fly it now, mommy! RACHEL
In a minute, hon. Let Gage finish his turn.
This is the last moment of happiness in this man's life-- make it very happy. As he and GAGE stare up at the kite: IRWIN (voice)
Jesus. Louis. I'm sorry--

The fight has gone out of IRWIN and STEVE has backed away cautiously. He's ready to jump back in if one or the othe mad again. But IRWIN is shuffling toward LOUIS, hands out everyone else has gathered in a knot near the front of th Among them is RACHEL and her mother, weeping in each othe IRWIN
I don't know what happened to me. Louis, please-- LOUIS brushes by him with no acknowledgement that IRWIN e exists. He kneels down slowly by the coffin and puts his against it. LOUIS (weeping)
I'm sorry, Gage--I'm so sorry, little hero.

location: LOUIS AND GAGE, IN THE FIELD

text: There's a strong gust of wind. The ball of string falls o GAGE'S hand.
ELLIE
It got away from him! That numb shit! RACHEL (outraged)
Ellen Creed!
It is bouncing and unraveling. More importantly, it is be carried directly toward the highway.
He takes off after the ball of twine. GAGE
Kite fline too fast! SOUND: The oncoming truck.
Slamming toward us--a brutal leviathan on eighteen wheels
He's looking--looking toward his people at the picnic tab LOUIS (shrugs, good-humored)
What can you d- TRUCK SOUND CONTINUES.
Alarm hits JUD'S face. He rises. JUD
Don't let him go in the road, Louis! RACHEL looks; registers terrible alarm. RACHEL (screams)
Get him, Louis!
He's still scampering after the bouncing ball of kite-twi has now almost reached the road. TRUCK SOUND LOUDER.
The SOUND is loud enough so he's having trouble hearing. LOUIS (cups his ear)
What?
RACHEL (shrieks)
JUD is running toward the road, although he'll never get in time; only LOUIS has a chance.
Horrible understanding dawns on his face. He whips around sees:
The kid's almost in the road; the ball of twine is in it. RISING DRONE OF THE TRUCK.
GAGE (cheerful)
Geddit-geddit-geddit!

GAGE reaches the middle of the road as the truck comes ar corner. LOUIS is running across the field, getting close side of the road. RACHEL is clutching ELLIE by the picnic JUD is helplessly trying to wave the truck down as it pas
As he reaches the broken white line he grabs the ball of SOUND OF THE ONCOMING TRUCK. GAGE turns his head. GAGE (not afraid)
Druck!
Suddenly THE DRIVER'S face turns into a Halloween mask of He BLASTS THE AIR-HORN.

location: LOUIS, ON THE VERGE OF THE ROAD

text: LOUIS (shrieks)

BLARE OF THE AIR-HORN. A shadow falls over his face. Ther audible CLICK! and we FREEZE FRAME. What we have now is a dously winning photograph of a little boy, not quite two, ball of string in his hand...and a shadow lying across hi

a.) LOUIS is pushing RACHEL out of a hospital door. RACHE wheelchair and looks radiantly happy (so, for that matter LOUIS). I think we may safely assume that the small blank bundle in RACHEL'S arms is GAGE. b.) LOUIS, bare to the waist, is tubbing a two-month-old baby-tub. He's laughing. The infant looks confused but ca c.) The whole family by the Christmas tree, following an present-opening. ELLIE, about five, has a doll in each ha and RACHEL are in pajamas. GAGE, about five months, is ly drift of wrapping paper. He looks confused but calm. d.) A child's sneaker lying in the road. It's splashed wi e.) GAGE--he's about nine months old in this snap--is pro in the angle of a sofa. There's a big white rabbit in his GAGE looks c. but c. f.) ELLIE and GAGE, bundled up against the Chicago winter is pulling a child's chair-sled. GAGE is propped up in th He's about eleven months old in this snap. He's laughing. g.) The Orinco tanker, overturned on the far side of Rout h.) This one was taken at Gage's first birthday party. He wearing a party-hat and looking at a birthday cake with a candle on it while LOUIS kisses one cheek and RACHEL kiss other. i.) LOUIS, in the road. He's holding GAGE'S jumper, which blood-soaked, and inside out. LOUIS is looking up toward and screaming. j.) Here is a full-face studio portrait of GAGE. He is sm us, heartbreakingly lovely. CAMERA HOLDS ON THIS while: JUD (voice)
Sedative finally took hold. She's asleep.

He's holding the studio portrait in his hands and looking fixedly. The other photos (the good ones, that is; not th screamers--those, we may assume, exist only in LOUIS'S to memory) are scattered on the table. We only saw a few; th actually hundreds. LOUIS puts the photo down as JUD comes in and crosses to fridge. LOUIS'S nose is badly swelled. He also has a blac JUD gets a couple of beers and comes back toward the tabl JUD
Your father-in-law packs a wallop, for an old guy. He and his wife gone back to Chicago? LOUIS
No...squatting out there at the Holiday Inn like a couple of vultures. He really thinks Rachel's going to go back with them. Her and Ellie. JUD
Louis-- The swing door opens. They look toward:
She looks dazed and shocked. There are brown circles unde eyes, but otherwise her complexion is much too white. She wearing fuzzy pj's. She's carrying the picture of her pul on the sled.

location: JUD AND LOUIS, AT THE TABLE

text: ELLIE (coming to the table)
I want to go back to my own room. I can't sleep with mommy. She keeps stealing the covers. JUD
What you got there, Ellie? At first she doesn't want to show him, but JUD is very ki JUD (studying it)
Why that's real nice...you pullin' him on a sled. Bet he liked that, didn't he? ELLIE nods. She is starting to cry. JUD is also leaking a eyes. ELLIE (crying)
I used to pull 'im a lot. LOUIS, looking down at his hands, nods. ELLIE

I'm going to carry this picture, Mr. Crandall, until God lets Gage come back. JUD reacts violently. And LOUIS looks up, dully curious.. hasn't the thought already passed through LOUIS'S mind? Y think it has. JUD
Ellie...God doesn't do things like that. I know you loved y'brother, but-- ELLIE

He can if He wants to. He can do anything, just like Inspector Gadget on TV. But I have to keep things ready for him, that's what I think. I've got his picture and I'm going to sit in his chair-- LOUIS
Ellie-- ELLIE
And I'm going to eat his breakfast cereal, too, even though it tastes like boogers. And...and... She bursts into tears. JUD
Louis, take care of your little girl...she needs you.
His face is stricken.
LOUIS comes in with ELLIE in his arms. He puts her gently bed and pulls the covers up. She's already mostly asleep. LOUIS (kisses her)
Good night, Ellie. ELLIE
G'night daddy. He starts for the door.
ELLIE
God could take it back if He wanted to, couldn't He? If He really, really wanted to? Can I have faith in that?
He stands looking at her for a long time, apparently thin about this quite deeply. LOUIS
Yes--I suppose you can. Good night, Ellie. He steps out, closing the door.
In some sense comforted--it may be a poison comfort but s doesn't know this--she turns over on her side to go to sl can see the picture of GAGE under her arm.
The light here is fairly dim. LOUIS goes down and opens a door. He pokes his head in.
He reacts first with surprise, then a species of horrifie disgust.
CHURCH is crouched on RACHEL'S sleeping form.
LOUIS comes in and swats the cat a damned good one. LOUIS (low snarl)
Fuck off, hairball!!
It hisses at him through a mouthful of fangs, its eyes bi balls...and then it flees. CAMERA FOLLOWS IT out the door
RACHEL stirs and mutters thickly, then lies still again.. doped to the gills. LOUIS bends over and kisses her gentl He leaves the room and closes the door behind him.
He tries the door a couple of times to make sure it's fir the latch (his face wears an expression of "How'd he get in the first place?"). Then he walks down the hall to the
The cat is on one of the risers. LOUIS trips over it.

For a moment he's pinwheeling madly for balance, on the v falling. He regains his balance as the cat goes shooting the dining room toward the kitchen. LOUIS regains his equilibrium after a bit and continues o

location: THE KITCHEN, WITH JUD AND LOUIS AND CHURCH

text: As LOUIS enters through the swing door from the dining ro is just letting CHURCH out the back door. As JUD closes t LOUIS (slightly antagonistic)
I thought you'd be gone by now. JUD
I got you a fresh beer out of the fridge, Louis. He indicates the table, where there is indeed a fresh bee LOUIS
Jud, I buried my son today and I'm very tired. I wonder if we could just-- JUD
You're thinking of things best not thought of, Louis. LOUIS
I'm thinking about going to bed. But he begins pouring the beer into a glass. JUD
You never asked me if anyone had buried a person up there in the Micmac burying ground-- LOUIS'S hand jerks. Beer goes foaming across the kitchen JUD
--but I think the thought has crossed your mind. LOUIS
Shit! Look at this mess! JUD
Ayuh--it's a mess, all right. As LOUIS goes to get a cloth to wipe up the mess: JUD
I know the Micmacs thought it was a holy place...and then they thought it was a cursed place. That's why they moved on. LOUIS
Because something called a wendigo soured the ground. JUD
And because the dead walked. LOUIS stops sopping and looks at him.
JUD
Oh, ayuh. It's been done. What you've been thinking of has been done.

head_text.subj: EXT. A COUNTRY RAILROAD STATION/SEPIA DAY

text: The time is the late summer of 1944, although I don't bel need to know that specifically. The sign on the station r LUDLOW. There are a few 40s cars parked near the station- have gas-ration coupons on the windshields. And a hearse. A train is coming.

location: THE HEARSE, WITH UNDERTAKER AND BILL BATERMAN/SEPIA

text: We can see the UNDERTAKER is trying to talk to BILL BATER man in his forties who periodically wipes his brow with a BILL walks away. He doesn't want to talk; he doesn't want He's a grief-stricken, bitter man. JUD (voice over)
Timmy Baterman was on his way home from the war with his Purple Heart when he got killed in some stupid car accident down in Georgia.

location: THE TRAIN, IN FRONT OF THE DEPOT/SEPIA

text: The door of the mail-car is open. The UNDERTAKER and thre trainmen are unloading TIMMY BATERMAN'S coffin, which is a 48-star flag. BILL BATERMAN stands by, watching baleful they carry his son's final apartment to the back of the h load it in. JUD (v-o continues)

Bill was bitter--his son had been in the thick of it two years and then got shot in the leg--a clean flesh-wound. He was supposed to be coming home safe and sound. Instead, he come home in a box after all.
The doors close. The hearse pulls away. THE CAMERA PANS T BATERMAN, who stands staring balefully after it and moppi brow. JUD (v-o continues)
He wasn't able to get to the bottom of the truth, Louis.

head_text.subj: INT. THE CREED KITCHEN, WITH LOUIS AND JUD NIGHT

text: LOUIS is now sitting down, drinking a beer, staring at JU LOUIS
I'll bite--what's the bottom of the truth, Jud? JUD
Why...that sometimes dead is better. That's all. Sometimes dead is better. LOUIS (bitter)
Tell that to my wife and little girl. JUD
It ain't your wife and little girl that's got me worried, Louis.

We're featuring a fresh grave...that of TIMMY BATERMAN. A showing only parking lights, turns into the graveyard and slowly up to it. It stops, and BILL BATERMAN gets out. HE the grave and then goes to the back of his truck. JUD (voice-over)
Timmy was buried on July 22nd, as I remember.

head_text.subj: EXT. BILL BATERMAN AT THE BACK OF HIS TRUCK/SEPIA DUSK

text: He reaches in...and brings out a pick and shovel.

head_text.subj: EXT. MARGIE WASHBURN, ON HER PORCH/SEPIA DAY

text: She's a middle-aged woman dressed in mid-forties style. S a rug-beater in one hand; the other is up to her eyes to sun. She's staring at something, horrified. JUD (v-o continues)
It was four or five days later when...

head_text.subj: EXT. A COUNTRY DIRT ROAD, WITH TIMMY BATERMAN/SEPIA DAY

text: A young man dressed in jeans and a plaid shirt is shambli road. His eyes are vacant. His shirt is half untucked. Hi sticking up in a wild crow's-nest thatch. There is an ugl healed scars on his neck and one side of his face. I thin his ears may be gone--torn off in the accident. JUD (v-o continues)
...Margie Washburn seen him walking up the road toward Yorkie's Livery.
She's screaming--we hear her faintly.
He turns toward her and we see a green light like the St. fire in the Little God Swamp glow dimly deep in his eyes. at MARGIE.

location: IN FRONT OF THE LUDLOW TOWN OFFICES, WITH MARGIE/SE

text: She hesitates for a moment or two and then walks up towar door. JUD (v.o.)
Lots of people saw Timmy Baterman walking back and forth between the home place and the town line. But  it was Margie...
She's in a hallway in front of a door with LUDLOW SELECTM printed on the frosted glass. After a moment she opens it in. JUD (v.o. continues)
...who finally got up enough guts to talk to the town fathers about it. She knew it had to be stopped, Louis.
MARGIE and four men are grouped around a desk. She's talk they're listening. THE CAMERA LAZILY PANS the four men--o course, is JUD as a YOUNG MAN. JUD (v.o. continues)
She knew it was an abomination. George Anderson, the town postmaster, was there...and Alan Purinton...Hannibal Benson...and me. I was there.

It's a ramshackle old farm which looks remarkably like th of that gentleman farmer Jordy Verrill. An old Ford pulls into the driveway, and the four men get SOUND BLEEDS IN: Most of all the SOUND OF THE CRICKETS. They go to the door, and JUD is wordlessly elected as the honcho. He knocks. No answer. Again. No answer. SOUND: Crazy laughter. BILL BATERMAN (voice)
Stop that, Timmy! The four men look at each other. JUD
Come on. They start around to the back.

location: THE BACK YARD, WITH BILL AND TIMMY/SEPIA

text: TIMMY BATERMAN is staring directly into the setting sun, glowing with green fire. He's laughing like Goofy gone in BILL, scared, is trying to make him stop, to turn away fr sun.
The four men come around the side of the house. They free they see BILL and TIMMY. ALAN
Oh holy Jesus lookit that. BILL whirls around and sees them. BILL
You men get out of here! JUD
I heard your boy was killed down Georgia. BILL (agitated)
That was a mistake! HANNIBAL
Was it? BILL
You see him standing there, don't you? Now get out! Get the Christ off my land! Now TIMMY turns around and comes shambling forward. TIMMY (laughing)
Ge ow! Ge Cwise off eye an! GEORGE (revolted)
Oh Jesus, Jud! He's dead! I can smell him! BILL
He ain't dead! Give him a day or two and he'll be fine! Don't you say that! JUD
Bill, this ain't right--you can see that yourself-- BILL (screaming)
TIMMY (laughing)
Dead! We love dead! Hate living! Abruptly he reaches up with both hands and scratches down cheeks, goring deep grooves in his flesh. Blood flows slu out. Very weird blood.

BILL grabs TIMMY, who's still laughing wildly, and gets h around. TIMMY shambles back to where he was originally st BILL goes with him like a man who has charge over a train baboon. A stupid trained baboon. BILL (over his shoulder)
You want to get out of here before I get my shotgun! You boys are trespassing!
JUD
God help you, Bill.
BILL (snarls)
God never helped me. I helped myself.
Staring directly into the setting sun and laughing wildly mindlessly.

location: THE CREED KITCHEN, WITH LOUIS AND JUD

text: LOUIS
What happened?
a.) A car pulls up with its lights off and stops. JUD (v.o.)
There was a fire. b.) We see legs as people get out of the car, and hands h tin cans of gasoline. c.) Hands splash gasoline from the cans along the sides o house.
JUD (as a young man) rings the bell--an old-fashioned twi BILL (voice)
Who's there? TIMMY (laughing, screeching voice)
Ooo air? Ooo air? JUD
Get out, Billy--the place is going up. He walks away. BILL BATERMAN, wearing a strappy tee-shirt out the window. BILL
I seen you! I seen you, Jud Crandall!

a.) A match is struck...and applied to wet boards. Whoosh b.) The other side of the house: The same. c.) In the back yard, JUD lights a torch and heaves it th kitchen windows. Ka-PLOOM! d.) The men draw away toward the front, their faces grim judgmental.
Burning. Going up fast.
ALAN
You think Bill's gonna get out, Jud? JUD (stony)
If he don't, he don't.
It bursts open. We see two men struggling at the forefron inferno--correction, one man and an undead monster. TIMMY giggling and screaming, trying to pull his father back in flames. BILL (struggling)
No! No, Timmy! Let me go! TIMME (laughing)
Love dead! Hate living! He sinks his teeth into his father's arm. BILL screams. A beam falls on TIMMY, lighting him afire. BILL breaks fr runs down the porch steps.
He's burning and laughing. TIMMY
And into the fire he goes, still shrieking and laughing.

BILL BATERMAN is collapsed on the lawn as sparks drift do him, his face hidden against his thighs, weeping. CAMERA MOVES SLOWLY IN on the four men, who are grouped a of the driveway by the road and staring with awe at:

location: THE KITCHEN, WITH LOUIS AND JUD

text: JUD (softly)
Sometimes dead is better, Louis. BLACK. And on it, a sixth title card: THE DEAD WALK. SOUND BLEEDS IN: JET ENGINES.
A jet plane rises into the sky from behind the building. GATE AGENT'S VOICE
This is the final call for United's flight 61 to Chicago...

location: A BOARDING GATE, WITH LOUIS AND RACHEL

text: In the b.g. we can see IRWIN and DORY GOLDMAN waiting by jetway with ELLIE as the last few passengers board. RACHE confused and grief-stricken. She also looks punchy, doped imagine she's floating on a sea of Valium, and that makes easier to deal with. LOUIS'S battle-scars are fading a li The GATE AGENT is standing by the jetway with a mike in o and a bunch of boarding passes in the other. GATE AGENT (concludes)
All passengers should now be aboard. LOUIS
You better get going, hon. RACHEL
Oh Louis, I just don't know about this-- LOUIS
I told you last night--this can be the start of patching things up with your folks. If something good doesn't come of Gage's death, I think I'll go crazy. RACHEL
Louis, are you sure? LOUIS
I'm sure.
ELLIE
I don't want to go to Chicago, Gramma Dory. DORY
Why not, darling? ELLIE
I had a bad dream last night. A nightmare. IRWIN (kindly)
About what? ELLIE
About Daddy. (Pause) And Gage. DORY and IRWIN exchange a knowing, sad glance over the ch head. ELLIE
And someone named Paxcow.
LOUIS guides her to the jetway. LOUIS
Come on, you guys--before you miss the boat. He kisses DORY. IRWIN hugs him. IRWIN
Louis, I am sorry. What can I say? That I lost my mind? It's the truth, but no good excuse. LOUIS (hugs him back)
We all lost our minds, Irwin. LOUIS kisses RACHEL. Then he kneels and hugs ELLIE. LOUIS
Be good to your mother, darlin'. She needs you. ELLIE
Come with us, daddy. Please come with us! LOUIS
I'll be there in three days--four at the most. I've got to get the electricity shut off and square things with your school so the truant officer ain't after you, and--
ELLIE (crying)
Please, daddy! I'm scared!
LOUIS
Of what? ELLIE (crying harder)
I don't know. LOUIS (great emphasis)
Everything's going to be all right, Ellie. Now go on--get aboard. ELLIE
Do you swear? LOUIS

I swear. The Voice of Authority has spoken. We can tell by ELLIE'S that while things are still not all right, they are a lit better. She joins her mother. The four of them--RACHEL, ELLIE, and THE GOLDMANS--start jetway. ELLIE looks back once, as if begging him to come. then they're gone.
LOUIS'S face changes. Now it is a stony and contemplative Not, when you get right down to it, a very nice face. He turns and strides away.

location: THE AIRPORT PARKING LOT, WITH LOUIS

text: The family station wagon is in the f.g. We hear the SOUND ENGINES, and as LOUIS reaches the wagon he turns and watc
From behind it a United Airlines jet lifts into view and away.
Face set, he gets into the wagon and drives away.
The CREEDmobile pulls up across from the Brewer Tru-Value and LOUIS crosses to it.
On it: A six-cell flashlight, Duracell D-batteries, a pic shovel, and a nylon drop-sheet in cellophane packaging. N CLERK'S hands come into the frame and drop a pair of heav gloves into the pile.
CLERK
Anything else for you today? LOUIS (after a look)
I think we got it all. The CLERK starts to ring things up. CLERK
Looks like heavy work. LOUIS
It could be. The quality of LOUIS'S reply is somehow unnatural. The CL at him, momentarily unsure and uncertain. Then he starts things up again.

location: A UNITED JETLINER, WITH ELLIE AND RACHEL

text: ELLIE is in the window-seat, asleep. RACHEL is holding a but not reading it. Her eyes are red. She's looking into CAMERA DRIFTS TO ELLIE. Her sleep is not easy. Her head t side to side, as if in negation. She becomes steadily mor She's starting to mutter. Suddenly her eyes flare open an screams.
We can see the GOLDMANS in the seats behind the CREEDS. T startled. So are other passengers. A stewardess comes run ELLIE
Paxcow says it's almost too late! RACHEL
Ellie...Ellie...what... ELLIE
Paxcow says it's almost too late! We have to go back! Paxcow says it's almost too late!
The CREED wagon turns in and drives up one of the lanes. and LOUIS gets out.
He walks to a fresh grave on which the first flowers are starting to wilt. He sits down and takes a flower. He plu looking at the grave steadily. He says nothing for a long LOUIS
It's wrong. (Pause) What happened to you is wrong.
He runs toward THE CAMERA, happy and laughing, in SLOW MO
LOUIS is now weeping, but he seems calm just the same. PASCOW (voice)
Remember, doc. LOUIS looks at:
PASCOW, bloody and mutilated, is standing by it. PASCOW
The barrier was not meant to be crossed. The ground is sour.
He is not put out of countenance in the slightest by PASC appearance; he probably knows PASCOW is just a figment of conscience or imagination, and so do we. LOUIS
I'll tell you where the ground is sour--the ground in my heart is sour. Let me tell you something else, Vic-baby: Wrong is wrong.
PASCOW
Timmy Baterman. That was wrong.
LOUIS
Don't talk like an asshole even if you are just a bit of underdone potato or a blot of mustard.
He stands mute, just looking.
LOUIS (weeping)
He was my son! He wasn't even two and he was run down in the fucking road and he was almost in pieces, and if you don't think I'm going to try...
VIC has put on his boogie shoes.
He's crying harder. Abruptly he reaches out at the floral and knocks a bunch of them over. LOUIS
If it doesn't work--if he comes back like Timmy Baterman--I'll put him to sleep. But I'm going to try. (Pause) And if it doesn't work...they don't ever need to know.

head_text.subj: EXT. THE GOLDMAN HOUSE IN LAKE FOREST, ILLINOIS NIGHT

text: THE CAMERA MOVES LEISURELY along this hallway, which is l pictures of RACHEL, ELLIE...and GAGE (there may even be a in which LOUIS is featured, but damned few). Near the end hall a door is open and light spills out. RACHEL (voice)
Honey, you just had a bad dream. You know that, don't you? ELLIE (voice)

It wasn't a dream. It was Paxcow. THE CAMERA GOES THROUGH THE DOOR and into the room where staying. She's in bed, still badly upset. RACHEL is sitti bed beside her. There's a single lamp on the bedside tabl ELLIE
Paxcow says Daddy's going to do something really bad. He-- RACHEL
Who is this Paxcow? Is he like the boogeyman? ELLIE
He's a ghost. But he's a good ghost. RACHEL turns off the bed-lamp. RACHEL
There are no ghosts, Ellie. I want you to go to sleep and forget all this nonsense. ELLIE
Will you at least call and make sure daddy's okay? RACHEL
Of course I will. She kisses ELLIE. RACHEL
Now will you try to go to sleep? ELLIE (turns over on her side)
Yes, Mom. RACHEL gets up and leaves the room.
PASCOW is here, halfway down the hall to the stairs, bloo ever. RACHEL doesn't see him. She looks perplexed, a woma to think of something. She stops very near him. RACHEL (to herself)
Paxcow, why do I know that name? PASCOW
Pascow. RACHEL suddenly straightens. She looks startled and afrai RACHEL
Pascow? Was she saying Pascow? She suddenly heads for the stairs, fast.

head_text.subj: EXT. THE CREED HOME IN LUDLOW NIGHT

text: SOUND: A car starting up. The station wagon backs out and heads down the driveway. passes THE CAMERA, we see LOUIS driving. The wagon turns Route 9 and heads off. CAMERA HOLDS ON THE HOUSE. A beat of silence. Then: the t starts ringing.

head_text.subj: INT. THE GOLDMAN LIVING ROOM NIGHT

text: IRWIN and DORY are watching RACHEL with some anxiety. RAC holding the phone to her ear. We can hear the FILTERED SO one ring after another. She hangs up. RACHEL
He's not home. DORY

Why, he probably went out for a hamburger or a chicken dinner, dear. You know how men are when they're alone. Good old IRWIN'S face says that maybe LOUIS went out for of grams of coke and a whore in Nazi SS boots. RACHEL is dialing another number.
SOUND: Phone starts to ring.
He shuffles to the telephone. His Walkman 'phones are aro neck. He's got a bottle of beer in one hand. JUD (picks up)
Hello--you got Judson.

location: THE GOLDMAN LIVING ROOM, WITH RACHEL

text: RACHEL
It's Rachel Creed, Jud. I'm calling from Chicago. JUD (surprised voice)
Chicago! Is Louis with you? RACHEL
No...we're going to be here awhile, and he wanted a few days to wind up our affairs there. I just wondered if he was with you.
His face says this is very serious. JUD
No--but if he drops by, I'll tell him to call you.
RACHEL
Jud, do you remember the name of the student that died on Louis's first day at work? The one that was hit by a car? JUD (voice)
I don't-- RACHEL
Was it Pascow?
JUD
Ayuh, I think 'twas. If I see Louis come home before I go to bed, I'll tell him to--

location: THE GOLDMAN LIVING ROOM, WITH RACHEL

text: RACHEL
Don't bother. I'm coming home. JUD (alarmed voice)
Rachel! RACHEL
Thank you, Jud. Goodbye. She hangs up.
JUD
No! Rachel! Don't do that! Rachel--! The buzz of an open line. Connection broken. JUD slowly r the receiver. The man looks very grim.

location: THE FRONT HALL OF THE GOLDMAN HOUSE

text: RACHEL comes down the stairs, dressed for travelling. She carrying a suitcase in one hand. Her parents meet her at of the stairs. DORY
Rachel...darling...you're upset... a night's sleep... RACHEL
I have to go. The connections are  tight, and I have to be at O'Hare in  forty minutes. Will you drive me, daddy? IRWIN
You know something's wrong, don't you? You know. And Ellie does, too. RACHEL
Yes. IRWIN
I'll drive you. ELLIE (voice)
Mommy? They all turn to:
ELLIE
Please hurry.
RACHEL
I will. Come and kiss me. ELLIE races into her arms.

SOUND Of a car engine, THROBBING AND LOW. It cuts off. CAMERA MOVES IN on the low stone wall between the cemeter road. Beyond it we can see the roof of the CREED station LOUIS appears, dressed in dark clothes. He looks both way tosses a big duffle bag over the wall. Stuff clanks insid LOUIS climbs over the wall, grabs his bag, and checks out scene.
A quiet city of the dead. Spooky. SOUND of crickets: Ree- ree...
He heads for GAGE'S grave.

location: THE GOLDMAN CAR, WITH RACHEL AND IRWIN

text: IRWIN
I'll come with you if you want, honey. RACHEL (shakes her head)
I've got three planes to catch and I got the last seats on two of them. It's like God saved them for me.

location: O'HARE UNITED AIRLINES TERMINAL, WITH IRWIN'S CAR

text: IRWIN'S car heads for it.

LOUIS approaches it slowly and sets down his bag of grave equipment. He sets aside the remaining floral tributes an opens the bag and takes out the spade. He looks down at t for a long second. LOUIS (low)
Gonna bust you out, son. He starts to shovel.
Digging...throwing...digging again. Already the shape of excavation is beginning to show. The work is easy; this e new and fresh.

location: JETLINER, IN A LINE-UP OF JETLINERS

I think she's praying.
Now it's pretty deep. Four feet, maybe. LOUIS is standing We see his feet as the shovel goes up and down, up and do

There's a white streak on the bottom of the grave--the to GAGE'S coffin. LOUIS swipes his hand through the loose di uncovering more, and then he begins to sweep off the top coffin with his hands.
JUD comes out. He's wearing a light jacket. His Walkman ' are around his neck. He's got a six-pack. He looks at:
It's dark.
He sits down. JUD

You done it, you stupid old man... now you got to undo it. He puts his earphones on. Cracks a beer. Lights a cigaret Pushes the PLAY button on the deck. Faint SOUNDS of The C buzz-sawing "Rock The Casbah." JUD begins to watch.
He climbs out of the grave and opens his duffle bag. He s pull out the pick. SOUND of an approaching car. LOUIS freezes.

text: A police car comes cruising slowly along. The spotlight o driver's side comes on and runs along the graveyard's sto
Watching. Waiting. Hardly breathing.
It reaches the end of the wall. Everything looks jake. Th spotlight goes out and the police car speeds up.
He relaxes perceptibly. He gets the pick and drops back i grave.

Here's a man on the thinnest edge between sanity and madn
SEATMATE
Think you'll make your connection in Boston? RACHEL
I have to.

We're looking up into his face. If GAGE had a POV, this w it. LOUIS'S face fills with a terrible grief. LOUIS
Oh, Gage--oh, honey.

His chin slips to his chest, even though we hear Creedenc 'phones and to him the sound must be at blastoff levels. long round ash on his cigarette in the tray. A couple of beer cans on the table beside him. A truck blasts by, startling him out of his doze. He jerk head up suddenly...and slaps himself. He's okay...for now
He is sitting on the edge of the grave, holding his dead his arms, rocking him. GAGE is back to us. We see only a limp figure in a dark suit. Hair flops limply. LOUIS
It's going to be all right...I swear it's going to be all right... The canvas tarp has been spread open to the right. LOUIS lay his son down on it.

text: It's littered with flower petals. One limp hand appears a them.
He closes the tarp over GAGE, making a roll. He then prod from the duffle bag. He cuts the rope and begins to tie o around one end of the canvas roll containing the corpse o son.
PILOT (voice)
Good evening again, ladies and gentlemen...
Her seatmate is knitting something. Across the aisle sits PASCOW, bloody but serene, hands clasped in his lap, look straight ahead. RACHEL looks around tensely. PILOT (continues)

I'm delighted to tell you that we've got a strong tail-wind tonight and we expect to arrive at Boston's Logan Airport almost on time. PASCOW clenches his fist in a "That's one for our side!" RACHEL (softly)
Thank God. Her SEATMATE looks at her a bit strangely.
He's got the bundle containing his son and the duffle-bag tools. He runs bent over. He reaches the wall and there's SOUND of another motor. He crouches at the base of the wa
Here comes that same police car. The spotlight runs along wall.
Crouching against his side of the wall and sweating.
It stops. The COP gets out. He walks slowly toward the wa

Crouched. Now we see the COP looking over the top. If he down...but he doesn't. Instead he turns around so we see LOUIS looks up, miserably scared, pouring sweat. Silence. Then: SOUND of the cop taking a whiz.
Ah! Relief. SOUND of his fly being zipped. He looks back cemetery for a moment. COP
I ain't afraid of no ghost. He walks back to his cruiser, gets in, and hauls ass.

He collapses with relief. Then he gets up and looks cauti over the wall. Nothing there but his car, parked a little on the other side of the road. He tosses the duffle bag over the top of the wall. He put canvas roll containing GAGE on top of the wall. Then he v over.

location: THE STREET SIDE OF THE WALL, WITH LOUIS

text: He takes the roll, gets the duffle bag hooked over his sh the string, and runs across the road like a soldier cross territory. He goes to the rear of the wagon.

location: THE REAR OF THE WAGON, WITH LOUIS

text: He puts the body down. He feels in his pocket for his key keys. Mild consternation. He looks around, feeling expose other pocket. Still no keys. More consternation. He begin feverishly through his pockets. Maybe in his jacket? Nope SOUND: An approaching car.
A civilian--not the ubiquitous cop.
He turns his pockets out, spilling change everywhere. Not Suddenly a little light goes on in his eyes. He goes to t driver's side of the car and looks in at:
The keys are in the switch.

He snatches the keys and returns to the back of the wagon the key to open the doorgate. He puts GAGE'S body in gent the duffle bag. He closes the doorgate and returns to the the car. He opens the driver's door and freezes. LOUIS returns to the rear, gets his keys from the doorgat back to the front, gets in, and drives away.
People are debarking into the gate area. Through them com RACHEL, running fast, pushing some people, excusing herse incoherently. PASCOW is walking near her. PASCOW
There's just time. If you run. Without looking at PASCOW, RACHEL takes off her shoes and
She's sprinting down the concourse--look out, Joanie Beno

text: The FEMALE GATE AGENT is starting to close the jetway doo PASCOW
Don't do that, babe. The GATE AGENT looks puzzled, as if she just had a though maybe a gas pain). She stops closing the door. RACHEL run the area. She sees:

location: THE JET PLANE, THROUGH THE GATE WINDOWS

text: It is just starting to swing ponderously away from the je

location: RACHEL AND FEMALE GATE AGENT, (PASCOW IS GONE)

text: RACHEL
Make it come back! FEMALE GATE AGENT
I can't-- RACHEL bolts down the jetway. The GATE AGENT stares after then runs for her stand, where we can see FLIGHT 61 and B the slide-cards. She picks up her mike.
RACHEL stands all alone at the end of it. AMPLIFIED SOUNDS OF JET ENGINES. RACHEL (screams)
It starts to swing back to pick her up.
PASCOW appears behind her and puts a hand on her shoulder PASCOW
You're doing just fine.
He's fast asleep with the tinny sound of Graham Parker co of his Walkman 'phones. SOUND: An approaching car.
The station wagon turns in and parks. LOUIS gets out. He back, removes the body in the tarp and the duffle bag fil tools. He manages to get everything together and walks to of the path. He looks at:
Off it goes, glimmering in the dark.
He holds the corpse of his little boy to him. LOUIS
Please God--let this work. He sets off.
Zonked out. He missed the whole thing. Nice going, Jud.

location: OUTSIDE THE ARCH TO THE PET SEMATARY, WITH LOUIS

text: Louis passes under like a ghost.
LOUIS is crying. He crosses to the deadfall. LOUIS
Ain't gonna stop, Gage. Ain't gonna look down. He begins to mount the deadfall.
He reaches the top. And woven into the deadfall, behind h facing the Pet Sematary, is that snarling face. LOUIS descends the other side.

location: THE FOOT OF THE DEDFALL, WOODS SIDE

text: LOUIS reaches the bottom and looks at:
The path winds onward through those gigantic trees--it gl slightly.

location: LOUIS, AT THE EDGE OF LITTLE GOD SWAMP

text: That phosphorescent glow is a lot more pronounced. SOUNDS CRICKETS and FROGS. The water is mucky and still. Hummock up like knobs on the back of a creature best not seen. Fo through the dead trees. LOUIS doesn't want to go in there man. I wouldn't either. But he does.

location: THE HERTZ DESK, AT BIA WITH RACHEL AND CLERK--AND P

text: PASCOW is lounging back against the rack of folders--and some of them bloody. HERTZ CLERK
I'm sorry...it's been very busy tonight. I really don't have anything. PASCOW
What about the Aries K with the scratch on the side? The CLERK starts looking through her papers. CLERK
I do have an Aries K, but it came in sort of beat up--there's a long scrape up one side-- RACHEL
I'll take it.

He comes walking toward THE CAMERA with GAGE in his arms duffle bag over his shoulder. Mist swirls around him. The landscape is weird, surreal. CRICKET SOUNDS, AMPLIFIED. I there are a lot of swampy, marshy SOUNDS--too many. It so almost prehistoric.
LOUIS stops. He looks slowly around at:
A demonic face takes shape in the mist and FLOATS SLOWLY THE CAMERA. It runs out a tongue that's about nine feet l Its eyes blow out. Blood and thick, gooey stuff runs from sockets.
He closes his eyes. After a moment he opens them.
Nothing there.
LOUIS
See? Just imagination. Just--
We can barely see them because they are thick in mist, bu standing on a couple of low, marshy tussocks. Suddenly a tentacle slimes its way out of the standing water and sli around his ankle.
LOUIS
Nothing...there. He turns around and begins to walk again.
The tentacle falls away.
MYRIAD SOUNDS, none of them pleasant--laughter, gobbling screams. Sounds like the swamp has been invaded by a pack escaped lunatics. LOUIS continues on regardless.

LOUIS comes into the frame. He's obviously tiring now, bu keeps moving along. SOUND: Approaching footsteps. Big ones. Thudding ones. So is coming which sounds approximately the size of a Tyrann Rex. And it just keeps getting louder and louder and loud looks plenty scared. SOUND: A falling tree.
Those SOUNDS keep getting closer and closer. Another tree we see this one. And now we see a SHAPE--just a SHAPE.
He's scared almost to death. His face turns up...up...up.

It is vaguely manlike: perhaps sixty feet tall, perhaps e don't see it very well, nor do we have to--I'm not even s flesh and blood. But there is a clear suggestion of a hea turns and looks down...looks at LOUIS CREED. We see great eyes the size of lighthouse lamps. It makes a huge GRUNTING SOUND...and then walks on.
The SOUND OF FOOTFALLS is slowly diminishing. LOUIS
It was the Wendigo. Dear God, I think the Wendigo just passed within sixty feet of me. Slowly he begins to walk again.
In the extreme f.g. is a tree which has just fallen--it i small tree, either, but a great big old fir. LOUIS approaches it. Stops. Looks at the tree. Looks down
Here is a gigantic animal track--if it was full of water, could swim in it. It looks like no animal track we've eve before. Three big claws at the end of it.
Looks up again. His face is set and hard. LOUIS
It doesn't matter. Come on, Gage. He starts to walk again.

SOUND: The wind, lonesome and keening. THE CAMERA MOVES SLOWLY toward the slope, dreaming its wa those rocky cairns...most of them burst apart. SOUND: Tortured breathing. Panting. LOUIS toils his way into view, carrying his bundle. He re top. He makes his way slowly into the burying ground. He over a rock. Falls down. Slowly gathers his things togeth gets up again. He goes a little further and then stops an at:
We can also see the shredded remains of a green garbage b
He slowly kneels down. He puts the canvas tarp to one sid slowly takes the pick and shovel from the duffle bag. By clearly a man approaching total exhaustion.

location: A COUNTRY ROAD, WITH AN ARIES K

text: It tracks past THE CAMERA.

location: THE ARIES K WITH RACHEL AND PASCOW

text: Both of them look tense. RACHEL is bolt upright behind th Suddenly, BANG! as one of the tires blow.
It goes skidding and slueing across the road, the rear ti off the rim. IT climbs the curb and hits a tree.
She lurches forward, but she's wearing her seat-belt--goo She unbuckles it and gets out.
She looks at the car, which now has quite a bit more wron than just a scratch up the side. RACHEL slumps, near tears. LOUIS isn't the only one who's through a lot tonight. RACHEL
Now what? PASCOW comes from around the tree as RACHEL walks to the looking for cars, or something. He looks urgent and upset PASCOW
It's trying to stop you. Do you hear me? It's trying to stop you. RACHEL looks around uncertainly...a little afraid. As she the scene she looks at--and through--PASCOW. RACHEL

Is anyone there? After a moment of silence she turns back to the road. Lig appear and brighten as a car approaches. RACHEL steps to shoulder and after a moment she sticks out her thumb, sur the first time in her life. The car sweeps by her without slowing.

LOUIS'S hands enter the shot and put a few more rocks on CAMERA PULLS BACK and we see him surveying his work. Besi the canvas tarp, now open and empty. Absently, LOUIS stuffs the tarp into the duffle bag (wher tools have also been replaced) and stands up with a wince hand goes to his lower back. He looks down at the cairn. LOUIS
Come back to me, Gage. Come back to us. He turns away toward the stairs.
She's walking down the shoulder with her high heels in on Lights. An approaching car. She turns, thumb out. The car by. RACHEL (shouts)

text: She starts walking again.
LOUIS is moving down the path. As he passes the tire swin pushes it, setting it in motion.
LOUIS slings the duffle bag wearily to one side and goes kitchen. CHURCH is under the table but LOUIS Doesn't see
SOUND of LOUIS slowly plodding up the stairs. He comes in dirty and exhausted, his hair hanging in his face. He wal the hall toward the master bedroom.
The clock on the bedtable reads 2:17 A.M. LOUIS falls fac on the immaculate bedspread and lies still. In this shot we should note the closet door is standing o

location: THE MICMAC BURYING GROUND, FEATURING GAGE'S CAIRN

text: THE CAMERA MOVES IN SLOWLY. Holds. Nothing for a beat. Th A small white hand slams up through the rocks, hopefully the living shit out of us. CAMERA MOVES CLOSER as the hand begins to feel around. It one of the rocks and pushes it aside. Another. Another. A The SOUNDS are not encouraging. It is GRUNTING and GROWLI is nothing human here. Rocks begin to tumble as GAGE starts to come out of his g
Fast asleep on the coverlet in his dirty jeans and black
My babe is still takin' a hike. But here comes another ve

location: THE DEADFALL IN THE PET SEMATARY

text: THE CAMERA MOVES IN on that snarling face. SOUNDS: GAGE coming. Dead dry breath. Low snarling noises Now we see small feet in dirty black shoes walking down t deadfall.
Suddenly, as the lights appear, she does a Claudette Colb pulling her skirt up and exhibiting a very lovely leg. Lights--it's an Orinco truck, naturally--spotlight her. T stops.
The driver leans over and opens the door. DRIVER
Hop in, baby. RACHEL
Thank you. She does.
He's under the kitchen table, green eyes gleaming. I thin loves dead, hates living. SOUND: The doorlatch. CHURCH MIAOWS.
GAGE'S shoes grit slowly across the linoleum, leaving dir tracks. CHURCH turns to watch GAGE'S passage, and then fo

CAMERA HOLDS ON LOUIS as those gritting footsteps approac we pan to the closet. On the floor is LOUIS'S little blac hold on this as the footfalls near. A small white hand en frame and pulls the doctor-bag out of the closet. Now ano enters the frame and opens the bag. The hands search arou and bring out a scalpel. They hold it up. The GAGE-THING makes a contented SOUND.

head_text.subj: EXT. THE ORINCO TRUCK, ON ROUTE 9 NIGHT

text: It sweeps past THE CAMERA

location: THE CAB, WITH RACHEL AND DRIVER

text: RACHEL
Can't you go any faster? TRUCKER
Lady, I got nine points on my license right now. RACHEL
I understand. It's just that-- She looks at him, pleading. The TRUCKER speeds up. RACHEL
Thank you. If you only understood how important this is-- TRUCKER
That's all right, babe. Only if we get stopped, next time I'll be the one hitchin' and you can give me a ride.

More deeply asleep than ever. Suddenly, from inside, come sound of Quiet Riot singing/screaming "Bang Your Head." I stereo, and boy, is it cranked. JUD straightens up so suddenly he almost falls off his ch hands go first to his earphones--his first thought on wak that it's coming from there--and then he hurries inside. CAMERA PANS DOWN to small muddy tracks on the porch floor

He hurries in, turns on the light, and rushes across to h system, which is state-of-the-art digital--it looks like saucer among the more traditional furnishings of the room shuts it off and looks around, frowning. SOUND: Todd Rundgren, singing "Bang on the Drum All Day" top of his voice. JUD'S head snaps toward the SOUND.
THE CAMERA PULLS BACK as JUD hurries across the kitchen t counter, where the radio is. He turns it off, looking aro bewildered than ever. JUD (sharply)
Who's here? He walks toward the door which gives on the hall.
It's dimly lit by light-spill from the living room and ki JUD

Come on, stop playing games! SOUND: Molly Hatchet, "Flirtin' with Disaster," being pla end, from upstairs. JUD hurries up. Let me suggest that there is a certain ps at work here--for the moment he's more concerned about wa neighborhood with all this high-decible rock and roll tha the prowler...and he would certainly know who--or what--t prowler was, if he had time to think.
He enters and turns on the light. We see a portable phono with the record, turning. JUD rushes over and turns it of He looks around, and we see by his face that he knows. JUD
Gage? (Pause) Are you the one playing games? He goes to the window and looks out at:

location: THE CREED HOUSE, WITH THE STATION WAGON, JUD'S

text: He turns slowly and walks toward the bed. JUD
Gage? Come on out. He reaches in his pocket and brings out a pocket-knife. H the blade. JUD
I want to show you something. SOUND: Miaow!
JUD (to the cat)
How did you--?!
A small hand holding a scalpel shoots out from beneath th of the coverlet and slashes JUD'S calf,
He screams with pain and staggers backward.
The other hand shoots out. GAGE grabs one of JUD'S ankles pulls.
With a startled yell, he falls.

This one's gotta be pretty rough. George will know what t finally see GAGE, but it should be clear to us that it's really GAGE at all. Some daemonic presence is riding insi mouldering, disfigured shell of GAGE. There is a struggle. JUD is repeatedly slashed with the s Perhaps he gets GAGE a time or two with the pocketknife. GAGE screams and gibbers--nothing intelligible here; only JUD expires. GAGE sits on top of him...and then bites into his throat.

text: Headlights. RACHEL'S truck has arrived. It pulls up. RACHEL opens the passenger door, which is on JUD'S side.
We can see PASCOW sitting in the passenger seat where RAC was. RACHEL
Thank you so much. TRUCKER
